(e)  License validity. The license year shall begin April 1 of each year and shall terminate at 12:00 midnight on March 31 of the following year. All business licenses or duplicates thereof shall be renewed on or before April 1 of each successive year upon the payment of the fees and proof of payment of the personal property taxes as prescribed in this section. Late renewals shall pay double fees. The city clerk shall prorate the amount of the license fee for the first license year on a monthly basis. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15-4; Code 1997, § 14-34; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 7-21-2003; Ord. No. 845, 2-27-2012) 
Sec. 10-23. - Assignability of business licenses. 
    Business licenses shall not be assignable. However, any person may agree to surrender the license to the city clerk for cancellation contingent upon the city clerk issuing a new business license to a person to be designated by the party surrendering the license for cancellation. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15-5; Code 1997, § 14-35; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 10-24. - Duplicate licenses. 
    Upon application to the city clerk, a duplicate business license may be issued to replace any license that may have become lost or destroyed. Such license shall clearly be marked as a duplicate and shall be a replacement of the original license. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15-6; Code 1997, § 14-36; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 10-25. - Cancellation of license. 
    The city clerk shall cause to be canceled on the records required to be kept under the provisions of this article any business license for any business, commercial, professional or service establishment which ceases to operate within the city for a period longer than 30 consecutive days. This section shall not apply to any such establishment which at the time of securing such business license, or any time thereafter, shall notify the city clerk that such business, commercial, professional or service occupation is seasonal in nature and will not be conducted on a continuous basis throughout the calendar year. If such notice is furnished to the city clerk, the prospective occupant or holder of such business license shall advise the city clerk in writing of the dates when such operations shall be conducted. Failure to maintain such business, commercial, professional or service operation during the periods of time indicated shall be grounds for cancellation of the business license. Any party feeling aggrieved by such cancellation may appeal such action of the city clerk in accordance with procedures set forth in section 10-21. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15-7; Code 1997, § 14-37; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 10-26. - Utilization of fees. 
    All fees received for the issuance of a business license shall be credited to a special fund as may be designated by the city comptroller, and shall primarily be utilized for the purpose of improving or maintaining ecological, environmental or aesthetic values of any area zoned for business, commercial, professional or service operations within the city, or for any other purpose as may be designated by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15-8; Code 1997, § 14-38; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 5-17-1999; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 10-27. - Posting of notice in business establishments. 
(a)  The owner of any building located within the city, which building is within a commercial or restricted office zoning district, shall cause to be displayed and shall maintain a copy of the following notice upon the inside of the rear door of such building or in some other conspicuous location within the building, such notice to read as follows: 
Notice-This building shall not be occupied by a tenant or owner without such tenant or owner first having obtained a business license from the City of Grosse Pointe Woods. 
(b)  Notice forms shall be on file and available from the city clerk and shall be four inches by seven inches minimum size. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15-9; Code 1997, § 14-39; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 10-28. - Changes in license status. 
    Any person or entity obtaining a business license is responsible for notifying the city clerk if any of the following occur: 
(1)  The licensee vacates or moves from the property referenced in the existing license. 
(2)  The licensee sells or otherwise transfers the interest in the license. 
    Failure to notify the city clerk constitutes a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 866, 11-16-2015) 
Sec. 10-29. - Going out of business sales. 
    The city hereby incorporates by reference Public Act 39 of 1961, regulating "going out of business sales" and other similar types of sales as defined in the Act (MCL 442.211 et seq). Persons conducting such sales as defined by the Act shall follow the Act's requirements and obtain a permit from the city clerk in accordance with the Act. A violation of this section, if prosecuted as a City Code offense, is a 90-day misdemeanor with fines as provided in Public Act 39 of 1961. 
(Ord. No. 866, 11-16-2015) 
Secs. 10-30-10-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BILLIARDS, POOL, BOWLING 

Sec. 10-58. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Billiard and pool means and includes the several games played on a table known as a billiard table, surrounded by an elastic ledge or cushions with or without pockets, with balls which are impelled by cue, and shall include all forms of games known as carom billiards, pocket billiards, three-cushion billiards, English billiards and all other games played on a billiard table and shall also include the so-called games of pool which shall include the games of 15-ball pool, eight-ball pool, rotation pool, bottle pool and all other games played on a so-called pigeonhole table. 
    Billiard and pool room means a public place where games of billiards and pool are permitted to be played. 
    Bowling means any of the several games played on a level surface with balls which are thrown by the hand at wooden pins and shall include all forms of games known as ten pins, nine pins, duck pins or any other game played on a bowling alley. 
    Bowling room means any public place where the game of bowling is played or permitted to be played. 
(Code 1975, § 4-7-2; Code 1997, § 14-111) 
Sec. 10-59. - Alcoholic liquors restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, licensee, manager or employee of any bowling alley, billiard or pool room to consume alcoholic liquors on the premises unless duly licensed therefor, and it shall be the duty of each of the aforesaid persons to enforce or cause to be enforced this section. 
(Code 1975, § 4-7-9; Code 1997, § 14-112) 
State Law reference- Alcoholic liquor licenses, MCL 436.1501 et seq. 
Sec. 10-60. - Employment of minors. 
    No minor under the age of 16 years shall be allowed to work in any bowling alley, billiard or pool room; and the minors who have attained their 16th birthday and not completed their 17th birthday working in such places must have working permits issued by the superintendent of schools in the district in which such person resides. 
(Code 1975, § 4-7-10; Code 1997, § 14-113) 
State Law reference- Youth employment standards act, MCL 409.101 et seq.; employment of minors, MCL 419.301 et seq. 
Sec. 10-61. - Gambling, obstructions to exterior vision prohibited. 
    No dice shall be thrown nor shall pool or shake pool be used for gambling, nor shall cards be raffled or other games of chance or any form of gambling be permitted in any billiard, pool or bowling room or in the room in which such tables are located or at any cigar stand or any other business in the same room, whether or not such room is divided by a partition, nor shall any checks be given which can be redeemed for merchandise or cash. No screens or other obstructions shall be placed in the doors or windows of such billiard, pool or bowling room, and such windows and doors must at all times be free and clear of such screens or other obstructions so as to permit an unobstructed view into such billiard, pool and bowling room. This section, however, shall not be construed to prevent the giving of cards or merchandise prizes to billiard or pool players or bowlers in a tournament league or any other competitive play. 
(Code 1975, § 4-7-11; Code 1997, § 14-114) 
State Law reference- Gambling, MCL 750.301 et seq. 
Sec. 10-62. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to private residences, schools or municipal institutions. 
(Code 1975, § 4-7-13; Code 1997, § 14-115) 
Secs. 10-63-10-82. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMMERCIAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-83. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Arcade means any place of business, establishment or room open to the public wherein five or more commercial amusement devices are installed. 
    Commercial amusement device means an instrument, machine or contrivance which may be operated or set in motion upon the insertion of a coin or token or the use of which may be permitted by the payment of a fee, and which provides amusement, information or entertainment. Not included in this definition are devices that furnish music and which are commonly referred to as jukeboxes, scales for the purpose of giving weights, medical devices providing blood pressure readings and bowling lanes. 
    Off-street parking space means a space of a minimum of 19 feet by nine feet located within 300 feet of the main entrance of the establishment intending to install or having installed one or more commercial amusement devices, such space being accessible for the parking of a motor vehicle and not located upon the streets or alleys within the city. 
    Owner means any person who occupies or conducts any place of business, establishment or room set aside in any commercial establishment in which any commercial amusement device is installed. In the case of a partnership, each partner shall be deemed an owner. In the case of a corporation, the officers of the corporation shall be deemed to be the owners under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-1; Code 1997, § 14-251) 
Secs. 10-84-10-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-110. - Required. 
(a)  No owner shall install or permit the installation of any commercial amusement device in any premises under such owner's control without first having obtained a license for such device from the city clerk. No such commercial amusement device shall be permitted to operate or remain within any premises of any owner without a valid license for such device being in existence for such machine at such location. 
(b)  No arcade shall be established or maintained within the city without the owner first having obtained an arcade license from the city clerk. No arcade shall be operated in the city without a valid arcade license being in existence for such location. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-2; Code 1997, § 14-271) 
Sec. 10-111. - Requirements to obtain. 
(a)  Any owner desiring to install one or more commercial amusement devices shall first file an application for a license with the city clerk upon forms approved by the city clerk. Any such application shall be accompanied by the payment of the license fee, to the city, in the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time for each commercial amusement device for which a license is sought. 
(b)  Any owner desiring to install or desiring to have in operation five or more commercial amusement devices at one location shall first obtain an arcade license for the location from the city clerk, in addition to the commercial amusement device licenses required for the individual commercial amusement devices to be located in such arcade. There shall be no additional fee for an arcade license. 
(c)  The license application required by this section shall state the name and address of the owner of the proposed installation, the number of commercial amusement devices, a description of such machines, the manufacturer's name and address, the serial number of such machines, if available, and the proposed location of each machine within the premises, including the distance in feet from any wall, table, chair or other obstruction. 
(d)  The city clerk shall not approve or issue a license for any commercial amusement device unless all of the following conditions prevail: 
(1)  A distance of six feet of clear area shall exist in all directions measured from any part of the machine, except a machine may be placed against a wall, divider, or other obstruction on one side of a machine. 
(2)  All electrical wiring leading to such machine shall be installed in such a manner that no electrical wire shall be located on the floor surrounding the machine. 
(e)  The city clerk shall not approve or issue a license for an arcade unless the owner certifies to the city clerk that there are available, for the exclusive use of the arcade, two off-street parking spaces for each commercial amusement device to be installed in the arcade. Such off-street parking requirement shall be in addition to the number of off-street parking spaces required or approved for any existing occupancy of any business located in the same building or establishment wherein the arcade is proposed to be located. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-3; Code 1997, § 14-272) 
Sec. 10-112. - Renewal. 
(a)  Any owner may apply for the renewal of any commercial amusement device license issued under the provisions of this article by certifying to the city clerk that the same conditions prevail as existed when the original license was issued and by paying a license renewal fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time to the city for each license. Renewal licenses shall be issued for a 12-month period. If identical conditions do not prevail, the owner seeking any license renewal shall file a new application therefor and comply with the requirements for the issuance of a new license. 
(b)  Arcade licenses may be renewed upon application of the owner and the owner's certification to the city clerk that the same conditions prevail as existed when the original arcade license was issued. Renewal licenses shall be issued for a 12-month period. If identical provisions do not prevail, the owner seeking any such renewal shall be required to file an application for a new arcade license and shall comply with the requirements for issuance of a new license. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-5; Code 1997, § 14-274) 
Sec. 10-113. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued to any owner for any commercial amusement device may be revoked by the city council upon a finding by the city council that the licensee has violated any conditions of such license. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-7; Code 1997, § 14-275) 
Sec. 10-114. - Public liability and property damage insurance. 
(a)  No license shall be issued to any applicant under this article until the applicant shall have filed with and the same shall have been approved by the city comptroller, policies of public liability and property damage insurance in the minimum amounts as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(b)  The insurance required by this section shall be furnished by a firm or corporation duly licensed or permitted to do insurance business in the state. Such insurance shall be kept and maintained in continuous force and effect so long as the applicant shall be licensed under this article. No license shall be valid in the event of the cancellation of such insurance. 
(c)  There shall be attached to all liability insurance policies pursuant to the requirements of this section, and filed with the city clerk, the following endorsement in substantially the following form: 
In consideration of the premium stated in the policy to which this endorsement is attached, the company agrees the policy to which this endorsement is attached shall not expire, nor shall cancellation take effect, until after ten days' notice, in writing, by the company, shall have been given to the City of Grosse Pointe Woods at its offices. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-8; Code 1997, § 14-276) 
Sec. 10-115. - Nontransferability. 
    Licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-9; Code 1997, § 14-277) 
Sec. 10-116. - Conditions of operation. 
    The owner of any establishment having one or more licensed commercial amusement devices shall: 
(1)  Have an adult supervisor on the premises and within the establishment at all times when the commercial amusement devices shall be operable or available for operation by the public. 
(2)  Not permit any commercial amusement device to be operated by any child under the age of 12 years unless such child is accompanied by his natural parent or legal guardian who remains on the premises while such child is operating the machine. 
(3)  Not permit such commercial amusement devices to be operated, except during the following hours: 3:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m., local time, Monday through Friday, September 10 through June 10 of each year; 10:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m., local time, Saturday and Sunday all year, and from June 11 through September 9 of each year. 
(4)  Not permit food or beverages to be in the area within six feet of any commercial amusement device. 
(5)  Not allow or permit any machines to be operated if such machines are determined to be unsafe after an inspection by the division of safety inspection. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20-6; Code 1997, § 14-279) 
Secs. 10-117-10-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CHRISTMAS TREES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-146. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling Christmas trees contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 4-6-1; Code 1997, § 14-176) 
Sec. 10-147. - Maintenance of site. 
(a)  The site upon which any business engaged in the selling of Christmas trees is permitted to be conducted shall be kept in a clean and orderly manner, and under no circumstances shall public streets, highways and places be encroached upon, nor shall there be any encroaching upon property other than that for which a license has been issued under this article. 
(b)  The licensee shall be responsible for the proper conduct of the business licensed under this article, and prior to the expiration of the license shall clean up the premises and shall remove all trees and debris to a place of disposal beyond the corporate limits of the city. No such trees or debris shall be disposed of by the burning thereof upon the licensed premises. 
(Code 1975, §§ 4-6-5, 4-6-6; Code 1997, § 14-178) 
Secs. 10-148-10-177. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-178. - Application; term of license. 
    Before engaging in the business of selling Christmas trees, an application, in writing, signed by the applicant, shall be filed with the city clerk stating, among other things, the applicant's address, the location of the proposed site where the business is to be conducted and the period for which a license is sought. The application must be accompanied by written evidence of the applicant's right to use the premises involved. All licenses shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance; provided that no license shall issue for a term exceeding 60 days. 
(Code 1975, § 4-6-2; Code 1997, § 14-211) 
Sec. 10-179. - Fee; bond. 
    The city clerk is authorized to issue licenses under this article upon payment of a license fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and the deposit of a cash bond in the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time by the applicant. This fee may be modified by a resolution of the city council as adopted from time to time. 
(Code 1975, § 4-6-3; Code 1997, § 14-212) 
Sec. 10-180. - Use of bond funds. 
    The cash bond required to be deposited under the provisions of section 10-179 shall be used by the city to reimburse itself for any expenses incurred in removing trees and debris and general cleanup of the premises for which the bond is posted, made necessary by reason of the failure of the licensee to comply with the provisions of this article. Any unexpended balance of the bond shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Code 1975, § 4-6-7; Code 1997, § 14-213) 
Secs. 10-181-10-198. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDDLERS, VENDORS, SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Home solicitation sales, MCL 445.111 et seq.; transient merchants, MCL 445.371 et seq.; charitable organizations and solicitations act, MCL 400.271 et seq.; public safety solicitation act, MCL 14.301 et seq.; veteran's license for peddlers, MCL 35.441 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-199-10-219. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-220. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a vendor, a peddler, a hawker or a huckster, or a house-to-house solicitor and canvasser or a refuse vendor, as hereinafter defined without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-1; Code 1997, § 14-731; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 10-20-1997) 
Sec. 10-221. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    House-to-house solicitor and canvasser means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot or any type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether such individual is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
    Peddler means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot or any type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, dairy products or similar or like articles, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a conveyance; and further provided that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this article. The term "peddler" shall include the terms "hawker" and "huckster." 
    Refuse vendor means any person, other than an employee or contractor, or employee of a contractor, of the city public works department, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot or any type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street and removing or carting away any materials left curbside for collection under the provisions of chapter 34. A refuse vendor shall not collect, remove or cart away any paper, glass, plastic or metal cans. A refuse vendor shall not collect, remove or cart away any materials between the hour of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following morning. 
    Vendor means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot or any type of conveyance who shall carry, convey or transport, from street to street, goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck farm products or provisions, dairy products or other similar or like articles for the purpose of making sales and deliveries to residents, merchants or places of business. The provisions hereof shall be deemed to mean and include sales and deliveries made from milk wagons, bread trucks and/or provision trucks operating over established routes or making sales and/or deliveries to established customers. 
(b)  It is expressly provided that the definitions of "peddler" and "vendor" shall not be deemed to apply to such businesses or business transactions wherein the order is taken or the purchase is made at the regular and permanent place of business, which order or purchase is thereafter delivered to residents or merchants of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-2; Code 1997, § 14-732; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 10-20-1997) 
Sec. 10-222. - Application. 
    Applicants for a license under this article must file with the clerk a sworn application, in triplicate, in writing on a form to be furnished by the clerk, which shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of applicant. 
(2)  Address (legal and local). 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer. 
(5)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with the state license number or other means of identification. 
(6)  Such other information as may be required by the clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-3; Code 1997, § 14-733) 
Sec. 10-223. - Investigation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such application for a license under this article, the original shall be referred to the department of public safety for investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as deemed necessary for the protection of the public good. Good moral character shall be construed to mean the propensity on the part of the person to serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest, and open manner, to be determined as provided in Public Act No. 381 of 1974 (MCL 338.41 et seq.). 
(b)  If as a result of such investigation the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the director of public safety shall endorse on such application such disapproval and such reasons for the same, and return the application to the clerk, who shall notify the applicant that the application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. 
(c)  If as a result of such investigation the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the director of public safety shall endorse on the application such approval and return the application so endorsed to the clerk. If the application shall be the initial application for a license by the applicant, such application shall be referred to the council, and if the council shall determine that such applicant is a suitable, reputable and desirable person to engage in the business for which the application for a license has been filed, and that the business to be conducted thereunder is not detrimental to public safety, health and welfare, the council, by appropriate action, shall approve such application; otherwise, the application shall be denied. 
(d)  Vendors' licenses for use on the day of the annual fireworks display within the city, or the rain date for such fireworks display, shall be limited in number by resolution adopted by the city council. Such licenses may be restricted for use in areas of the city as established by council resolution. License costs for such licenses shall be established by resolution of the city council from time to time adopted. Such licenses may be restricted in number as to the type of merchandise to be offered for sale by the vendors. Individual licenses shall be issued to each employee of a vendor who shall receive an ID badge or card from the city, the costs of which shall be established or adopted by council resolution from time to time. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-4; Code 1997, § 14-734; Ord. No. 725, § 1, 5-18-1998) 
Sec. 10-224. - License fees. 
(a)  Upon approval of any application for a license under this article, the clerk shall issue the required license. 
(b)  The fees for any license issued under the provisions of this article or any renewal thereof, excepting licenses issued for the July 4th celebration or the rain date thereof shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(c)  The license fees shall be payable to the city clerk upon approval of the license application. 
(d)  For all annual licenses issued after September 1, the fee shall be one-half of the amounts stated in subsection (b) of this section. 
(e)  For all licenses issued for a vendor or peddler, such license shall be valid for use from 9:00 a.m. to dusk or 7:00 p.m., local time, whichever occurs first. 
(f)  The number of licenses issued and outstanding for a refuse collector shall be limited to five in number. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-5; Code 1997, § 14-735; Ord. No. 725, § 1, 5-18-1998; Ord. No. 736, § 1, 5-3-1999; Ord. No. 752, § 1, 6-19-2000; Ord. No. 861, 4-13-2015) 
Sec. 10-225. - License plates and cards. 
    The clerk shall issue to each vendor or peddler licensed under this article a metallic plate or card which indicates the year for which the license was issued. If a vehicle is used by the licensee, the metallic plate shall be attached in a conspicuous place upon the vehicle. If no vehicle is used by the licensee, the card must be carried upon the licensee's person and displayed upon the request of any officer of the department of public safety or customer. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-6; Code 1997, § 14-736) 
Sec. 10-226. - Renewals. 
    Licenses issued under this article may be renewed from time to time by a previously licensed applicant in good standing and the filing of an application as provided in section 10-222; and upon approval by the director of the department of public safety of the applicant's character and business responsibility, and upon payment of proper license fees. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-7; Code 1997, § 14-737) 
Sec. 10-227. - Transfer of license. 
    No license issued under this article shall be transferred to or used by a person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-8; Code 1997, § 14-738) 
Sec. 10-228. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  Any license issued under this article may be revoked by the council after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the business as solicitor or as canvasser. 
(3)  Any violation of the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(5)  Conducting the business in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  No refund of any license fee shall be made upon the revocation, cancellation or surrender of a license. 
(c)  Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at the licensee's last known address at least ten days prior to the date set for hearing. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-9; Code 1997, § 14-739) 
Sec. 10-229. - Appeal. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the action of the clerk or the director of the department of public safety in the denial of a license applied for under this article shall have the right of appeal to and a hearing before the council. 
(b)  Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the council, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The council shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided in section 10-228 for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the council in such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-10; Code 1997, § 14-740) 
Sec. 10-230. - Prohibited where posted. 
    No person shall conduct a solicitation at a residence or other building within the city on which there is displayed a sign in public view reading "no solicitors." This sign shall not exceed three inches by 12 inches in size and shall have letters one inch or greater in size. 
Sec. 10-231. - Ice cream vendor-Equipment. 
    Any vendor, as defined in this article, who utilizes a motor vehicle to sell or offer for sale ice cream, ice milk, frozen dairy products or ice flavored with syrup, to persons other than at the entrance to the residence of such persons, shall, in addition to the meeting the general requirements for vendor's license, have such vehicle equipped with the following: 
(1)  Signal lamps mounted at the same level and as high and as widely spaced laterally as practicable. These lamps shall be five inches to seven inches in diameter and shall display two alternately flashing amber lights on the front of the vehicle and two alternately flashing red lights on the rear of the vehicle. Both front and rear lights shall be visible at a distance of 500 feet in ordinary sunlight. 
(2)  A stop signal arm that can be extended horizontally from the left side of the truck duplicating the design, sign size and specifications shown in subsection (4) of this section. This arm shall be red and white in color and contain two alternately flashing lights on each face of the arm, three inches to five inches in diameter and visible at a distance of 300 feet in ordinary sunlight. The color of the two lights facing to the front shall be amber and the color of the two lights facing to the rear shall be red. The bottom of the signal arm shall be 42 inches above the highway. 
(3)  The vehicle shall contain a convex mirror mounted on the front so that the driver, in his normal seating position, can see the area in front of the truck obscured by the hood. 
(4)  The stop signal arm required by subsection (2) of this section shall be constructed in such a manner that it substantially complies with the diagram on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-12; Code 1997, § 14-742) 
Sec. 10-232. - Same-Use of special lights and signal arm. 
    The operator of an ice cream vending truck shall, when stopped upon the streets of this city for the purpose of vending, activate the special flashing lights and extend the stop signal arm during the time such truck is stationary. The special lights and signal arm shall not be utilized while moving. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-13; Code 1997, § 14-743) 
Sec. 10-233. - Same-Operation of trucks. 
    The driver of an ice cream vending truck shall vend only when the truck is lawfully parked or stopped. Such truck shall not vend to persons standing in the street, nor shall such truck be backed up to make or attempt to make a sale. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-14; Code 1997, § 14-744) 
Sec. 10-234. - Same-Duties of motorists. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle meeting or overtaking an ice cream vending truck stopped on the street shall stop before reaching the vending truck when the flashing lights and stop signal arm are in use. After stopping, a driver may proceed past such truck at a reasonable and prudent speed, not exceeding 15 miles per hour, and shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian who crosses the roadway on or from the ice cream vending truck. 
(Code 1975, § 4-1-15; Code 1997, § 14-745) 
Secs. 10-235-10-261. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STREET SALES AND SOLICITATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 877, adopted Dec. 14, 2017, amended former Art. VII, §§ 10-262-10-265 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1975, §§ 2-16-1-2-17-4; Code of 1997, §§ 14-956-14-959. 

Sec. 10-262. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means a natural person as defined by Chapter 1, Sec. 1.2 and includes charitable or civic organizations as defined in this section. 
    Charitable or civic organization means a non-profit organization that is qualified under Sec. 501(c)(3) or 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code, 26 USC 501, or a veterans' organization that has tax-exempt status under the internal revenue code. 
    Street sales and solicitations means the sale of goods or the solicitation of donations by persons using the streets of the city and attempting to or making such sales or attempting to or receiving donations from persons in motor vehicles upon the city streets. 
(Ord. No. 877, 12-4-2017) 
Sec. 10-263. - Permit required. 
    Any charitable or civic organization desiring to conduct street sales or solicitations shall first obtain a permit authorizing such activity from the city clerk or the clerk's designated representative, at least 72 hours in advance of any such activity. 
(Ord. No. 877, 12-4-2017) 
Sec. 10-264. - Requirements for permit. 
    Any charitable or civic organization requesting a permit authorizing street sales or solicitation shall provide information as required by the clerk's office and comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Provide proof of the organization's status as a civic or charitable organization; 
(2)  Identify the dates, times, and location of the proposed sales/solicitation; 
(3)  Provide proof of liability insurance naming the city as an additional named insured in an amount of at least $1,000,000.00; 
(4)  Any person soliciting on behalf of the organization must be 18 years of age or older; 
(5)  Any person must wear high-visibility safety apparel that meets current American standards promulgated by the International Safety Equipment Association; 
(6)  The portion of the roadway upon which the solicitation occurs cannot be a work zone and must be within an intersection where traffic control devices are present; 
(7)  Sales/solicitations must occur during daylight hours. 
(Ord. No. 877, 12-4-2017) 
Sec. 10-265. - Revocation of permit. 
    The director of public safety or the director's authorized representative may immediately revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this article for noncompliance with the conditions of this article by any person making sales or solicitations. 
(Ord. No. 877, 12-4-2017) 
Sec. 10-266. - Violations. 
    Any person violating this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction with fines in accordance with section 2-813, as may be modified by council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 877, 12-4-2017) 
Secs. 10-267-10-293. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RESIDENTIAL HANDBILLS 

Sec. 10-294. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Residential handbills means papers, booklets and pamphlets of printed matter, excepting materials primarily containing political or religious materials, delivered by individuals to residential homes or apartments within the city, but does not include papers, letters, booklets or pamphlets delivered by the United States postal service or to daily or Sunday newspapers delivered over an established route or to magazine or telephone books delivered to subscribers by a private delivery service. 
(Code 1975, § 4-23-1; Code 1997, § 14-931) 
Sec. 10-295. - Delivery to posted property. 
    No person shall deliver or deposit residential handbills at any residential home or apartment where a sign or notice has been posted in a conspicuous location, which sign or notice states "no handbills" or "no vendors or solicitors." This sign shall not exceed three inches by 12 inches in size and shall have letters one inch or greater in size. 
(Code 1975, § 4-23-2; Code 1997, § 14-932) 
Sec. 10-296. - Violation of article; warning notice; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall deliver or deposit a residential handbill at any residential home or apartment which has been posted as provided in this article shall receive a written warning notice of such violation. 
(b)  Any person who, having received a written warning under the provisions of this section, shall again be found to be in violation of the provisions of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be deemed to have been responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(c)  Any person who, having been found responsible for a civil infraction under the provisions of this article, shall be charged with a second or subsequent offense with violating the provisions of this article, shall be deemed, upon conviction thereof, to be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1975, § 4-23-3; Code 1997, § 14-933) 
Secs. 10-297-10-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - NEWSPAPER SALES RACKS 

Sec. 10-326. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building front setback line means that line formed at the outer surface of a building, structure or enclosure wall with the surface ground level on that portion of the building or structure facing the adjacent street. 
    Newspaper sales stand or rack means a device designed or used for the storage or display of newspapers, magazines, books or periodicals, which device stands alone or is affixed temporarily or permanently to another object. 
(Code 1975, § 4-9-1; Code 1997, § 14-691) 
Sec. 10-327. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Each person desiring to locate or place a newspaper sales stand or rack between a building front setback line and the curb of any adjacent street shall first make application for the approval of the proposed location for such sales stand or rack from the director of public safety. Such application shall be in writing and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The proposed location, giving approximate distances between the building front setback line and the curb of the adjacent street. 
(2)  The proposed location with reference to the nearest intersection. 
(3)  The proposed location with reference to the property address of the lot or building in front of which such newspaper stand or rack is proposed to be placed. 
(b)  Such written application may contain a request for more than one proposed location. 
(c)  The applicant for such permit shall furnish any additional information that may reasonably be required by the director of public safety in order that the director of public safety may determine whether or not the proposed location of such sales stand or rack offers any material hazard to traffic or to pedestrians. 
(Code 1975, § 4-9-2; Code 1997, § 14-692) 
Sec. 10-328. - Approval of location. 
    The director of public safety shall review each application for the proposed location of a newspaper sales stand or rack to determine whether such proposed location is desirable from the standpoint of traffic flow, traffic safety and pedestrian safety, and shall approve or disapprove such location accordingly, and shall notify the applicant in writing within 30 days of the receipt of such application of such approval or disapproval. 
(Code 1975, § 4-9-3; Code 1997, § 14-693) 
Secs. 10-329-10-359. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PRECIOUS METAL AND GEM DEALERS 

Sec. 10-360. - Certificate of registration-Required. 
    No person shall engage in the ordinary course of repeated and recurrent transactions of buying or receiving precious items from the public as defined in Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.) without first having obtained a certificate of registration from the director of public safety. 
(Code 1975, § 4-19-1; Code 1997, § 14-901) 
Sec. 10-361. - Same-Fee; application. 
    The fee for the certificate of registration required by this article shall be adopted by council resolution from time to time. The applicant shall furnish the information required by Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), when applying for the certificate of registration. 
(Code 1975, § 4-19-2; Code 1997, § 14-902) 
Sec. 10-362. - Reports of transactions. 
    Each dealer in precious metals or gems required to be registered under the provisions of Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), shall furnish to the public safety department a record of each transaction on forms approved by the department, and such reports shall contain the information required by Public Act No. 95 of 1981 and shall be filed with the department of public safety as required by state statutes. 
(Code 1975, § 4-19-3; Code 1997, § 14-903) 
Secs. 10-363-10-408. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MASSAGE PARLORS AND ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 10-409. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Massage means the rubbing, kneading, tapping, compression, vibration, application of friction or percussion of the human body or parts of it by hand or with an instrument or apparatus. 
    Massage establishment and massage parlor mean a business establishment where massagers practice massage, a building, room, place, or establishment, other than a regularly licensed hospital or dispensary in which body massage is practiced on the human body, for other than cosmetic or beautifying purpose, with or without the use of nonpowered mechanical or bathing devices. The term "massage parlor" includes a health club, health spa or any physical fitness club that offers massage on occasion or incidental to its regular operation. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1117; Ord. No. 733, § 1, 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 10-410. - Certification. 
    Massagers employed within the city shall be certified in therapeutic massage by a national board for therapeutic massage and bodywork. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1117; Ord. No. 733, § 1, 3-15-1999) 
Secs. 10-411-10-431. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - FOOD SERVICE 

Sec. 10-432. - Adopted by reference. 
    The law relative to food service establishments and vending machines dispensing perishable foods and beverages, otherwise known as Public Act No. 92 of 2000 (MCL 289.1101 et seq.) is hereby adopted by reference to article XIV of this chapter, governing health and sanitation within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 3-6-1; Code 1997, § 14-401) 
Sec. 10-433. - Enforcement. 
    Where Public Act No. 92 of 2000 (MCL 289.1101 et seq.) is applicable, it shall be enforced in conjunction with article XIV of this chapter. However, where such Act and article XIV of this chapter differ as to conditions, controls, requirements or standards, the more stringent conditions, controls, requirements or standards shall govern. 
(Code 1975, § 3-6-2; Code 1997, § 14-402) 
Secs. 10-434-10-464. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - RESTAURANTS 

Sec. 10-465. - License. 
(a)  Required; posting. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant who does not possess an unrevoked license of current issue as provided in this article. Such license shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article shall be entitled to receive and retain such a license. 
(b)  Contents of application. A written application for such license shall be made to the clerk on forms provided at the office of the clerk and shall contain the following: 
(1)  Whether the applicant is a person, partnership, firm, corporation or organization. 
(2)  The names and addresses of the persons, members of partnerships or officers of the firm, corporation or organization making application. 
(3)  The name and address of the restaurant. 
(4)  The type of restaurant. 
(5)  The capacity of the dining room. 
(6)  An agreement to permit the county health officer to inspect the restaurant and everything in connection with it, to interview the employees at any reasonable time, and that the applicant will give true and complete information to the county health officer concerning the operation of the restaurant. 
(7)  The date of application. 
(8)  The signature of the applicant. 
(c)  Investigation by county health officer. The clerk shall, upon receiving such application, refer it to the county health officer to investigate the facts stated in the application and sanitary conditions in and around the place wherein it is proposed to operate the restaurant specified in the application. 
(d)  Approval of application and issuance of license. If it is found by the county health officer after investigation that the statements contained in the application are true and that the existing sanitary conditions in the place wherein it is proposed to operate the restaurant conform to the sanitary requirements of this article, the county health officer shall approve the application and return it to the clerk, who shall issue a license to the applicant permitting the applicant to operate the type of restaurant designated in the application, and no other, upon payment of a fee as provided in this section. 
(e)  Fee. The fee for a license as provided for in this section shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, and provided further that no fee shall be charged for a license granted to a fraternal, religious, educational or social organization. 
(f)  Disapproval of application. If it is found by the county health officer after investigation that the statements contained in the application are not true or that the applicant is not operating or cannot operate a restaurant conforming to the sanitary requirements of this article, the county health officer shall disapprove the application and return it to the clerk with a detailed statement of the reason for the disapproval. 
(g)  Review of disapproval. The clerk shall, upon receipt of such disapproval, present it with the application to the council at its first regular meeting which will allow the serving of ten days' notice upon the applicant, and shall, on or before ten days before such regular meeting, serve or cause to be served upon the applicant a notice of disapproval of the application by the county health officer, and the date of the regular meeting at which the application will be presented to the council. The council shall consider the disapproval of the county health officer and shall hear the applicant on the applicant's behalf, and shall act upon the application. The council shall establish its own rules of order for such review and hearing. If the application is denied by the council, the clerk shall give written notice to the applicant within five days of such denial and such applicant shall not open the restaurant designated in the application to the public thereafter. 
(h)  Suspension or revocation authorized. The county health officer shall have the power to revoke or suspend the license of any restaurant which is not or cannot be operated in conformance with the requirements of this article, by giving written notice, stating therein the reasons for such action of suspension or revocation to the licensee. A copy of this notice shall be sent to the licensing authority. 
(i)  Review of suspension or revocation. In the event of suspension or revocation, the licensee shall be entitled to a hearing before the council, if the licensee presents a request for such hearing, in writing, to the clerk within ten days from the date of revocation or suspension of the license. Such hearing shall be started at the following regular meeting of the council, and the council, after hearing and considering both sides of the case, shall act as sole judge of whether or not the revocation or suspension shall take effect. The council shall establish its own rules of order for such review and hearing. 
(j)  Expiration; renewal. All applications for license renewal shall be made at least 30 days before the license expires. 
(k)  Approval of new construction or alterations. Plans and specifications for new construction or alteration of the existing restaurant shall be submitted to the county health department for approval before issuance of a building or construction permit. 
(Code 1975, § 3-4-4; Code 1997, § 42-31) 
Sec. 10-466. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Authority of county health officer. The county health officer shall have the authority and duty to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Inspections. At least once every six months, or as often as necessary, the county health officer shall inspect every restaurant. The county health officer shall have authority to enter any building or part thereof which is used, or which the county health officer has reason to believe is used, for the storage, preparation, sale, serving or distribution of food or drink for human consumption, to inspect the premises, furniture, equipment, dishes or utensils used therein, and to determine whether or not the sanitary requirements of this article are complied with. 
(c)  Order to correct violation. If, on inspection, the county health officer finds any violation of the requirements of this article, the county health officer shall issue an order to the licensee or person in charge of the restaurant directing the correction of such violation within such reasonable time as the county health officer shall deem proper. 
(d)  Failure to correct violation. If the county health officer finds a continuation of the violation upon a second inspection after such reasonable time, the county health officer shall suspend the license of the restaurant until such violation has been corrected. 
(e)  Immediate suspension of license and closing of business. If the county health officer finds unsanitary conditions in any restaurant such that the conditions would be immediately dangerous to the health of the general public, the county health officer may immediately suspend the license of and close the restaurant until such unsanitary conditions are corrected, following which the county health officer shall give a written notice in a reasonable time to the licensee or the responsible representative in charge stating the reasons for closing the restaurant. A continuance to operate after receipt of such written notice shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 3-4-5; Code 1997, § 42-32) 
Sec. 10-467. - Interpretation by council. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the county health officer in accordance with the interpretations which may be adopted by the council. 
(Code 1975, § 3-4-9; Code 1997, § 42-33) 
Secs. 10-468-10-487. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - VALET PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-488. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Valet parking means the taking of possession of a motor vehicle from the operator by a person for the purpose of parking such vehicle as a service to the customers or clients of a business establishment, whether or not a charge is imposed for such service. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1091; Ord. No. 676, § 1(4-24-1), 8-1-1994) 
Secs. 10-489-10-514. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-515. - Required. 
    A license issued by the city shall be required by any business establishment intending to employ or actually employing a valet parking service or persons performing such service, excepting those businesses whereat the valet parking operation is performed within the confines of the business property so serviced. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1111; Ord. No. 676, § 1(4-24-2), 8-1-1994) 
Sec. 10-516. - Application. 
    Any person or business entity desiring to employ or utilize valet parking as a service to their customers or clients shall apply to the city clerk for a license to conduct such valet parking operation. The application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name, legal status, address and telephone number of the applicant and the location where the valet parking service will operate. 
(2)  A diagram of the area to be utilized for the temporary dropoff and pickup of the motor vehicle showing the street involved, the nearest intersection and any on-street metered parking area to be utilized as a dropoff or pickup area. 
(3)  A statement and diagram showing where the vehicles will be parked by the valet parking employees. All vehicles accepted for valet parking must be parked in the designated parking area. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1112; Ord. No. 676, § 1(4-24-3), 8-1-1994) 
Sec. 10-517. - Review of application. 
    The application for a valet parking license shall be reviewed by the department of public safety, which shall determine whether or not the proposed pickup and dropoff area would create adverse traffic conditions. If, in the determination of the department of public safety, such proposed dropoff and pickup area will not create adverse traffic conditions, the department of public safety shall notify the city clerk of such fact and of the number of on-street parking spaces required for the dropoff and pickup area to be utilized by the valet parking operations. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1113; Ord. No. 676, § 1(4-24-4), 8-1-1994) 
Sec. 10-518. - Fees and time restrictions. 
(a)  The city clerk, upon receipt of the report from the department of public safety indicating the department's approval of the application for a license under this article, shall ascertain the number of metered on-street parking spaces that will be required for the valet parking operations and shall issue to the applicant a valet parking license. The applicant shall pay an annual licensing fee to the city in the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time for each on-street metered parking space to be utilized by the valet parking operations. The licensing fee shall be prorated on a monthly basis for every month or portion thereof from the date of issue of the license to the date of expiration of the license for each metered parking space utilized. 
(b)  The license to operate a valet parking service shall include the right to utilize the designated on-street metered parking spaces during the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight, local time, unless other times are approved by the department of public safety. During such time periods, the licensee shall be permitted to cover the parking meters or otherwise place signs in the area indicating that such parking spaces are reserved for or dedicated to the use of valet parking. 
(c)  No valet parking license shall be issued to any business unless such business has a valid city license to operate. 
(d)  No valet parking license shall be transferable to another business. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1114; Ord. No. 676, § 1(4-24-5), 8-1-1994) 
Sec. 10-519. - Revocation; hearing. 
    The city council shall have the authority to terminate any license for valet parking issued under the provisions of this article if the director of public safety recommends such action to the city council based upon a determination that the valet parking operation authorized by such license is creating adverse traffic conditions. The city council shall, upon receipt of such recommendation from the director of public safety, hold a hearing on such request whereat the licensee may be offered the opportunity to address the concerns of the director of public safety. At such hearing, the city council may determine to revoke the valet parking license or continue such license for a limited time subject to any restrictions determined by the city council to be necessary to correct the situation. Should the city council determine to revoke the license, the city clerk shall issue a refund of the licensee fees previously paid on a pro rata basis. 
(Code 1997, § 14-1115; Ord. No. 676, § 1(4-24-6), 8-1-1994) 
Secs. 10-520-10-546. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - HORSE RIDING ACADEMIES; STABLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-547. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating a riding academy or stable in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-1; Code 1997, § 14-491) 
Sec. 10-548. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Riding academy or stable mean any place of business operated for the purpose of boarding and housing of horses or furnishing saddle horses for hire. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-2; Code 1997, § 14-492) 
Sec. 10-549. - Premises to be kept clean. 
    The premises used for conducting a riding academy or stable shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and it shall be unlawful to permit the accumulation of refuse, manure and other offensive materials or substances upon such premises. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-5; Code 1997, § 14-493) 
Sec. 10-550. - Riding in specified places. 
    It shall be unlawful to ride a saddle horse upon any street, highway or public place other than that set aside for vehicular traffic; provided, however, that the department of public safety may establish bridle paths which saddle horses may be permitted to travel upon; such bridle paths shall be properly designated by signs erected by the department of public safety. It shall be unlawful to ride any saddle horse upon the space between the sidewalk and curb upon any highway or public place, or upon any sidewalk. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-6; Code 1997, § 14-494) 
Sec. 10-551. - Owner's responsibility for compliance. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of any riding academy or stable to properly advise patrons of the regulations imposed in this article, and the owner or operator of such riding academy or stable shall be responsible for the proper observance of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-7; Code 1997, § 14-495) 
Secs. 10-552-10-580. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-581. - Application; investigation of site. 
    Before engaging in the business of operating a riding academy or stable, the owner thereof shall make application in writing to the council for a license therefor, which application shall state the name of the owner, the location of the business to be operated and the general nature and character of such business to be so conducted. Upon receipt of any such application, the council shall cause an investigation to be made for the purpose of determining the suitability and adequacy of the site at which such business is to be conducted. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-3; Code 1997, § 14-526) 
Sec. 10-582. - Fee. 
    If the application for a license under this article shall be approved, such license shall be issued upon payment of the sum as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time to the city clerk next succeeding its issuance. Renewals of permits shall be made in the same manner as provided in this article for the original license. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-4; Code 1997, § 14-527) 
Sec. 10-583. - Revocation or suspension. 
    The council may, upon notice to any licensee, revoke or suspend any license issued under the provisions of this article upon proof of any violations of the provisions of this article or if any premises used for a riding academy or stable is kept in an unsanitary and unhealthy condition. 
(Code 1975, § 4-3-8; Code 1997, § 14-528) 
Secs. 10-584-10-614. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - TREE TRIMMING AND REMOVAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-615-10-631. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-632. - Required. 
    No person shall operate a tree trimming or tree removal service within the city without first obtaining a license to conduct such service from the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 4-16-1; Code 1997, § 14-1061) 
Sec. 10-633. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a license under the terms of this article shall make application for such license to the city clerk on forms provided. Each application shall be referred to the director of public services for the director's approval prior to the issuance of a license by the city clerk. The director of public services may withhold approval of an application if the applicant has been found guilty or pleaded guilty or no contest to a charge of violation of this Code concerning the removal and disposal of tree trimmings or stumps. 
(Code 1975, § 4-16-2; Code 1997, § 14-1062) 
Sec. 10-634. - Fee; performance bond. 
    Upon approval of the application for a license under this article, the applicant shall pay the sum as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time as a license fee to the city and shall file a performance bond in the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time with the city to guarantee that the licensee shall remove and dispose of tree trimmings, bush trimmings and stumps cut by such licensee from the premises whereat such services were performed. 
(Code 1975, § 4-16-3; Code 1997, § 14-1063) 
Sec. 10-635. - Display. 
    The applicant shall receive from the city clerk a license plate evidencing the fact that a license has been issued under the terms of this article. Such license plate shall be posted on the left side of any motor vehicle operated in connection with the applicant's business in a conspicuous location. If the applicant uses more than one motor vehicle, additional license plates will be furnished to the applicant at a charge as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1975, § 4-16-4; Code 1997, § 14-1064) 
Chapter 12 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan telecommunications act, MCL 484.2101 et seq.; metropolitan extension telecommunications right-of-way oversight act, MCL 484.3101 et seq.; Michigan broadband development authority act, MCL 484.3201 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Findings and intent. 
(a)  The city, pursuant to applicable federal and state law, is authorized to grant one or more nonexclusive franchises to construct, operate, maintain and reconstruct cable television systems within the city limits. 
(b)  The city council finds that the development of cable television and communications systems has the potential of having great benefit and impact upon the residents of the city. Because of the complex and rapidly changing technology associated with cable television, the city council further finds that the public convenience, safety and general welfare can best be served by establishing regulatory powers which should be vested in the city or such persons as the city shall designate. It is the intent of this chapter and subsequent amendments to provide for and specify the means to attain the best possible cable television service to the public, and any franchise issued pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed to include this finding as an integral part thereof. 
(Code 1997, § 18-1; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-1, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. 
    Broadcast basic cable service means any service tier which includes the retransmission of local television broadcast signals and educational and government access signals. 
    Cable television service means the total of the following: 
(1)  The one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service. 
(2)  Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other programming service. 
    Cable television system, system, cable communications system and cable system mean a facility consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service and which may include video programming, data transmission and other services which are provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations. 
(2)  A facility that serves only subscribers in one or more multiple unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management, unless such facility uses any public rights-of-way. 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming, data transmission and other services directly to subscribers. 
(4)  Any facility of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system. 
    Channel and cable channel mean a portion of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum which is used in a cable system and which is capable of delivering a television channel as defined by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). 
    Cities means the cities of Harper Woods, Grosse Pointe Woods, Grosse Pointe, Grosse Pointe Farms and Grosse Pointe Park. 
    Council means the city council. 
    Data transmission means any service that involves interactive communication of data and information between the grantee and subscriber. 
    Educational or government access facilities means the following: 
(1)  Channel capacity designated for educational or governmental use. 
(2)  Facilities and equipment for the use of such channel capacity. 
    Franchise means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the city council, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement or otherwise, which authorizes the construction or operation of a cable system. 
    Franchise agreement means a contractual agreement, containing the specific provisions of the franchise granted, including references, specifications, requirements and other related matters. 
    Franchise fee means the fee imposed by the grantor on a grantee or cable subscriber, or both, pursuant to section 12-39. 
    Grantee means any person receiving a franchise pursuant to this chapter under a granting franchise agreement and the person's lawful successor, transferee or assignee. 
    Grantor and city mean the city as represented by the council or any delegate acting within the scope of its jurisdiction. 
    Gross annual receipts means the annual gross receipts received by a grantee from all sources of operations of the cable television system within the city utilizing the public streets and rights-of-way for which a franchise is required in order to deliver such cable service, excluding refundable deposits, rebates or credits. Any sales, excise or other taxes or charges imposed on a grantee in addition to its franchise obligations and collected for direct pass-through to local, state or federal government shall not be included. 
    Initial service area means the area of the city which will receive service initially, as set forth in any franchise agreement. 
    Installation means the connection of the system to subscribers' terminals, and the provision of service. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, corporation or governmental entity. 
    Service area and franchise area mean the entire geographic area within the city as it is now constituted or may in the future be constituted, unless otherwise specified in the franchise agreement. 
    Street means each of the following which have been dedicated to the public or which are hereafter dedicated to the public authority or by others and located within the city limits: streets, roads, roadways, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way and similar public property and areas that the grantor shall permit to be included within the definition of street from time to time. 
    Subscriber means any person who elects to subscribe to, for any purpose, a service provided by the grantee by means of or in connection with the cable system and who pays the charges therefor. 
(Code 1997, § 18-2; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-2, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-3. - Uniform ordinance. 
    This chapter is based upon a uniform ordinance promulgated jointly by all five of the cities. It is intended that, to the greatest extent possible, the provisions of the separate ordinances enacted by each of the cities, based upon the uniform ordinance, be construed in a consistent and uniform manner. 
(Code 1997, § 18-3; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-40, 5-16-1994) 
Secs. 12-4-12-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FRANCHISE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 12-25. - Legislative requirement; purposes. 
    A franchise granted by the city under the provisions of this chapter shall encompass the following purposes: 
(1)  To engage in the business of providing cable television service and such other services as may be permitted by applicable law, to subscribers within the designated service area. 
(2)  To erect, install, construct, repair, rebuild, reconstruct, replace, maintain and retain cable lines, related electronic equipment, supporting structures, appurtenances and other property in connection with the operation of a cable system in, on, over, under, upon, along and across streets within the designated service area. 
(3)  To maintain and operate such franchise properties for the origination, reception, transmission, amplification and distribution of television and radio signals and for the delivery of cable services and for data transmission and other services. 
(4)  To provide and maintain a permanently installed automatic start engine generator and transfer switch system at the head end, which generator system will be automatically exercised weekly to confirm readiness status and which generator will automatically provide power in the event of commercial power failure within the head end. 
(5)  To provide, upon request, a parental control device which allows parents to lock out both audio and video from pay television programming. 
(6)  To set forth the obligations of a grantee under the franchise. 
(Code 1997, § 18-31; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-3, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-26. - Franchise required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or operate a cable television system in the city within any public street without a properly granted franchise awarded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18-32; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-4, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-27. - Term of franchise; renewal. 
(a)  A franchise granted under this chapter shall be for a term established in the franchise agreement, commencing on the grantor's adoption of an ordinance or resolution authorizing the franchise. 
(b)  A franchise granted under this chapter may be renewed upon application by the grantee pursuant to the provisions of applicable state and federal law and of this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18-33; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-5, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-28. - Franchise territory. 
    Any franchise shall be valid within all the territorial limits of the city and within any area added to the city during the term of the franchise, unless otherwise specified in the franchise agreement. 
(Code 1997, § 18-34; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-6, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-29. - Interpretation of chapter and applicability of other laws. 
(a)  This chapter shall be construed in a manner consistent with all applicable federal and state laws. Whenever any duly authorized federal or state agency shall exercise any paramount jurisdiction over any specific provisions of this chapter, such paramount jurisdiction shall preempt or preclude the exercise of like jurisdiction by the city. 
(b)  If the state or federal government has discontinued or shall discontinue preemption in any area of cable communications over which it formerly exercised or currently exercises jurisdiction, in such manner as to expand rather than limit municipal regulatory authority, the grantor may, if it so elects, adopt rules and regulations in those areas to the extent permitted by law. No such rules and regulations or other rules and regulations of the grantor shall apply to any franchise issued pursuant to this chapter prior to their adoption to the extent precluded by the express terms of the franchise agreement. The grantor may regulate rates and charges as provided under applicable law. 
(c)  This chapter and, to the extent permitted in subsection (b) of this section, any rules or regulations as may be promulgated from time to time shall apply to all franchises granted or renewed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
(d)  The city may amend this chapter, except that no amendment shall alter any provision of any franchise granted before the effective date of the amendment. 
(Code 1997, § 18-35; Ord. No. 658, § 4-18-7, 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 12-30. - Transferability. 
(a)  The grantee shall not sell, transfer, lease, assign, sublet or dispose of, in whole or in part, either by forced or involuntary sale, or by ordinary sale, contract, consolidation or otherwise, the franchise or any of the rights or privileges therein granted, without the prior consent of the council and then only upon such terms and conditions as may be prescribed by the council. Consideration of any such transaction shall not be unreasonably denied or delayed. Any attempt to sell, transfer, lease, assign or otherwise dispose of the franchise without the consent of the council shall be null and void. The granting of a security interest in any grantee assets, or any mortgage or other hypothecation, shall not be considered a transfer for the purposes of this section. 
(b)  The requirements of subsection (a) of this section shall apply to any change in control of grantee. The definition of "any change in control of grantee" shall be set forth in the applicable franchise agreement. 
(c)  The grantee shall notify the grantor in writing of any foreclosure or any other judicial sale of all or a substantial part of the franchise property of the grantee or upon the termination of any lease or interest covering all or a substantial part of such franchise property. Such notification shall be considered by the grantor as notice that a change in control or ownership of the franchise has taken place, and the provisions under this section governing the consent of the grantor to such change in control or ownership shall apply.
