The employees, agents or representatives of this state or a political subdivision of this state and nongovernmental disaster relief force workers or private or volunteer personnel engaged in disaster relief activity are immune from tort liability to the extent provided under section 7 of Public Act No. 170 of 1964 (MCL 691.1407). As used in this section, the term "disaster relief activity" includes training for or responding to an actual, impending, mock, or practice disaster or emergency. 
(d)  A person licensed to practice medicine or osteopathic medicine and surgery or a licensed hospital, whether licensed in this state, another state, by the federal government or a branch of the armed forces of the United States, or an individual listed in subsection (f) of this section, who renders services during a state of disaster declared by the governor and at the express or implied request of a state official or agency or county or local coordinator or executive body, is considered an authorized disaster relief worker or facility and is not liable for an injury sustained by a person by reason of those services, regardless of how, under what circumstances or by what cause those injuries are sustained. The immunity granted by this subsection does not apply in the event of an act or omission that is willful or gross negligence. If a civil action for malpractice is filed alleging an act or omission that is willful or gross negligence resulting in injuries, the services rendered that resulted in those injuries shall be judged according to the standards required of persons licensed in this state to perform those services. 
(e)  An individual listed in subsection (f) of this section, during a state of disaster declared by the governor, may practice, in addition to the authority granted by other statutes of this state, the administration of anesthetics; minor surgery; intravenous, subcutaneous or intramuscular procedure; or oral and topical medication; or a combination of these under the supervision of a member of the medical staff of a licensed hospital of this state, and may assist the staff member in other medical and surgical proceedings. 
(f)  Subsections (d) and (e) of this section apply to all of the following individuals: 
(1)  Any of the following, if licensed in this or another state or by the federal government or a branch of the armed forces of the United States: 
a.  A registered nurse. 
b.  A practical nurse. 
c.  A nursing student acting under the supervision of a licensed nurse. 
d.  A dentist. 
e.  A veterinarian. 
f.  A pharmacist. 
g.  A pharmacist intern acting under the supervision of a licensed pharmacist. 
h.  A paramedic. 
(2)  A medical resident undergoing training in a licensed hospital in this or another state. 
(g)  A person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to this state or a political subdivision of this state a license or privilege, or otherwise permits this state or a political subdivision of this state to inspect, designate, and use the whole or any part of the real estate or other premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, mock or practice disaster, together with his successors in interest, if any, is not civilly liable for negligently causing the death of or injury to any person on or about the real estate or premises under the license, privilege or permission or for loss or damage to the property of the person. 
(h)  A person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who has gratuitously granted the use of the real estate or other premises for the purposes stated in this section is legally obligated to make known to the licensee any hidden dangers or safety hazards that are known to the owner or occupant of the real estate or premises that might possibly result in the death or injury or loss of property to a person using the real estate or premises. 
(i)  As used in this section, the term "gross negligence" means conduct so reckless as to demonstrate a substantial lack of concern for whether an injury results. 
(Code 1975, § 2-13-9; Code 1997, § 30-39) 
Sec. 18-28. - Federal surplus property. 
    The emergency services coordinator is hereby designated as the person responsible for accepting federal surplus property with the power and full authority to sign for such surplus property. The mayor shall provide a written statement to appropriate federal officials designating the current name of the coordinator as responsible for complying with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  The coordinator is responsible for the accountability and will maintain the necessary records for all surplus property obtained for emergency purposes until relieved from accountability by state and federal authorities. 
(2)  The coordinator is further authorized to direct payment of service charges for surplus property to complete all transactions. 
(3)  Misappropriation or unauthorized private use of such public property while still accountable is subject to prosecution under federal and state statutes. 
(Code 1975, § 2-13-10; Code 1997, § 30-40) 
Chapter 20 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Natural Resource and Environmental Protection Act, MCL 324.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Rubbish, trash and weeds. 
(a)  Nuisance declared. The presence of dirt, trash, rubbish or weeds on the sidewalks and street rights-of-way adjoining commercial business establishments is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner, lessee or occupant, or any firm or corporation having charge of any lot or parcel of land being used for commercial or business purposes of any nature within the city, to permit or allow an unsightly amount of dirt, trash, rubbish or weeds to accumulate upon the sidewalks and street rights-of-way adjoining such lot or parcel of land. 
(Code 1975, §§ 3-7-1, 3-7-2; Code 1997, §§ 14-1, 14-2) 
Secs. 20-2-20-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public nuisances and abatement, MCL 600.3801 et seq. 

Sec. 20-21. - Creation or maintenance prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to create, cause to be created or to permit the existence of a nuisance in or upon privately owned property. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-1; Code 1997, § 34-31) 
Sec. 20-22. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means the creation of or the existence of any condition upon privately owned property that may result in or have a tendency to result in an unsanitary or unhealthy condition. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-2; Code 1997, § 34-32) 
Sec. 20-23. - Excavations below grade. 
    It shall be unlawful to excavate upon or remove the earth from any premises so as to create any hole or depression in or upon the premises where water may accumulate, or by removal of earth from such premises, which may reduce or lower the grade of such premises below that established upon adjoining public thoroughfares. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-3; Code 1997, § 34-33) 
Sec. 20-24. - Open drains. 
    It shall be unlawful to establish an open drain in and upon private property without first having obtained a permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of section 20-29(a). 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-4; Code 1997, § 34-34) 
Sec. 20-25. - Standing water. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit private property to exist in a condition that shall be of a grade below that of the grade of adjacent public thoroughfares. It shall be the duty of the owner of private property to cause any property existing in such condition to either provide adequate fill therefor or to provide adequate surface drainage, so as to eliminate the accumulation of surface water upon such premises. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-5; Code 1997, § 34-35) 
Sec. 20-26. - Accumulation of waste. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any rubbish, garbage or offal, paper, twigs, water deposit, glass, manure, filth, grass, shrubs or other similar or like offensive materials to accumulate upon private property that may create an unsanitary or unhealthful condition upon such property. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-6; Code 1997, § 34-36) 
Sec. 20-27. - Deposit of waste material. 
    It shall be unlawful to deposit or scatter rubbish, garbage or offal, broken concrete, bricks, paper, twigs, manure, filth, grass, shrubs or other similar or like offensive materials upon private property; provided that, if any such substance or materials may be required to make a fill, a permit therefor shall be first obtained as required in this article. If such permit shall be granted, after the fill has been completed, the entire surface where such fill has been made shall be covered with at least six inches of dirt spread evenly over such fill. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-7; Code 1997, § 34-37) 
Sec. 20-28. - Property owner's consent required for excavation or filling. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove earth from or deposit materials specified in section 20-27 upon the property of another without first having obtained such property owner's written consent, which written consent shall be filed with the clerk. Such operation shall be carried on in accordance with the provisions of this article and all other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-8; Code 1997, § 34-38) 
Sec. 20-29. - Permit for excavation, filling or installation of open drain. 
(a)  Application; bond; issuance. It shall be unlawful to undertake any excavation work or dirt removal work, any property filling, or installation of any open drain or ditch upon private property without first having obtained a permit therefor. Application for such permit shall be made to the city clerk and shall specify the nature of the work to be engaged in, the location of such work, the name and address of the owner of the property involved and the name and address of the applicant. If, because of the nature of the work to be engaged in, the clerk shall determine that, in order to safeguard the public health, a performance bond shall be required before any such permit shall be issued, such application shall be referred to the council for determination of the amount and nature of the bond to be required. The council may impose further conditions in the issuance of any such permit to safeguard the public interests, and upon determination of the nature and amount of the bond to be furnished and the conditions to be imposed, no permit shall issue until full compliance with the directions of the council shall have been made. 
(b)  Fee. The applicant, for any permit required under subsection (a) of this section, shall pay to the clerk a permit fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1975, §§ 8-7-9, 8-7-10; Code 1997, §§ 34-39, 34-40) 
Sec. 20-30. - Exception for work covered by building permit. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be deemed to apply to any construction work undertaken by reason of the issuance of a building permit under provisions of the building code. 
(Code 1975, § 8-7-11; Code 1997, § 34-41) 
Sec. 20-31. - Costs. 
    Costs incurred by the city to enforce this article may be assessed as a single lot assessment. 
Secs. 20-32-20-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OUTSIDE STORAGE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 20-51-20-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NONLICENSED OR INOPERABLE AUTOMOBILES, PANEL TRUCKS AND PICKUP TRUCKS 

Sec. 20-74. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable automobile, panel truck or pickup truck means any motor vehicle which is temporarily or permanently incapable of being moved under its own power and has not been moved for a period of 14 consecutive days, excepting those vehicles parked at the city car pound. Upon written application to the director of public safety or the director's designated representative by the owner of the inoperable vehicle or by the owner of the property where such vehicle is parked, the director of public safety or the director's designated representative may grant up to an additional 30 days' parking time for such vehicle upon a showing of necessity by such owner. 
    Nonlicensed automobile, panel truck or pickup truck means any motor vehicle, whether the vehicle is capable of operation or movement under its own power or not, which does not have attached thereto current and valid license plates registered for such vehicle and has not been moved for a period of 14 consecutive days, excepting those vehicles parked at the city car pound. 
(Code 1975, § 6-11-1; Code 1997, § 34-91; Ord. No. 672, § 1, 3-7-1994) 
Sec. 20-75. - Outside storage prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the registered owner of any nonlicensed or inoperable motor vehicle, panel truck or pickup truck or for any owner or tenant of any real property located within the city to allow or permit the outside storage of any nonlicensed or inoperable motor vehicle, panel truck or pickup truck upon such real property. 
(Code 1975, § 6-11-2; Code 1997, § 34-92) 
Sec. 20-76. - Costs. 
    Costs incurred by the city to enforce this article may be assessed as a single lot assessment. 
Secs. 20-77-20-93. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MOTOR VEHICLES AT GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS 

Sec. 20-94. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle that is designed to be self-propelled, whether the vehicle is operational or not. 
    Rental car means any four-wheel passenger motor vehicle held primarily for hire, lease or rental. 
    Service station bay means that area of the service station building designed for housing a motor vehicle within the service station. 
    Service station operator means that person who owns and operates the service station or who has the authority of the owner of the service station to operate and control the service station. In the case of copartnerships or corporations, the copartners and the officers of the corporation shall be deemed to be the service station operator. 
    Service station parking area means that land upon which the service station is located that is paved. 
(Code 1975, § 6-14-1; Code 1997, § 34-141) 
Sec. 20-95. - Compliance. 
    No service station operator shall permit the storage of any motor vehicle upon service station property except as provided in this division. 
(Code 1975, § 6-14-2; Code 1997, § 34-142) 
Sec. 20-96. - Permitted storage; maximum number of vehicles. 
(a)  Tow trucks. A vehicle designed for the towing of other motor vehicles, which is owned or leased by the owner or operator of the service station, may be parked upon the premises subject to the limitations of this division, provided that the number of such vehicles parked shall not exceed one per service bay. 
(b)  Disabled vehicles and vehicles awaiting repair. No other motor vehicle may be parked or stored upon service station property unless the vehicle is under repair, is awaiting delivery of parts or is disabled and awaiting removal by the owner of such vehicle. 
(1)  A vehicle under repair may be parked or stored upon the premises, provided that the vehicle is under repair pursuant to a contract for such repair made between the service station operator and the owner or lessee of such vehicle. Vehicles parked pursuant to this subsection may be kept upon the premises for no longer than 48 hours. Vehicles which must be parked for longer than 48 hours shall not remain unless the service station operator notifies, in writing, the director of public safety, or the director's representative, of the intention to retain such vehicle and the reason for such retention, together with a description of the vehicle. Upon such notification, the director shall approve an extension of time for parking for an additional five days only. 
(2)  The total number of vehicles parked upon service station premises shall not exceed the number set forth for that location as prescribed in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Parking space designation. No service station shall have parked upon its premises more than the number of vehicles allowed for that location as provided by the building official. 
(1)  The building official shall designate the maximum number of parking spaces allowed for each location based upon the number of square feet of available space, being the total area of the station less existing buildings and islands, with allowances for traffic lanes. The number of spaces shall be determined and the station notified promptly upon such determination. Should the operator of the service station disagree with the determination of the building official, review may be had to the city council, which may revise the determination upward, but not downward. Notice of the right to appeal shall be provided the operator of the facility when the designation of spaces is made. 
(2)  The building official shall determine the number of parking spaces available for vehicles under repair, awaiting parts or awaiting removal by the owner of such vehicle. Such parking space shall be at least ten feet by 20 feet in area. The building official shall first designate a parking space for each employee of the service station who is on the premises at the time of maximum shift, plus one parking space for the owner or manager of the station, plus two parking spaces for each service station bay. After designation of the required parking spaces for employees, for the owner or manager, and for the service station bays, any remaining parking spaces shall be designated for the parking or storage of motor vehicles under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 6-14-3; Code 1997, § 34-143) 
Sec. 20-97. - Prohibited storage; rental of parking spaces. 
    No owner or operator of a service station may rent, lease or otherwise permit the parking of a motor vehicle upon service station premises when the vehicle is not under repair, or owned or leased by an employee of the station. A violation of this section shall be presumed when a vehicle is parked continuously for five consecutive days between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., and permission for such parking has not been granted by the director of public safety. 
(Code 1975, § 6-14-4; Code 1997, § 34-144) 
Sec. 20-98. - Storage of rental cars. 
    Rental cars may be stored upon service station premises; provided, however, that such vehicles shall be parked in officially designated parking spaces and in compliance with subsection 20-96(b)(1). 
(Code 1975, § 6-14-5; Code 1997, § 34-145) 
Secs. 20-99-20-124. - Reserved.
