Chapter 22 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- State fire prevention code, MCL 29.1 et seq.; crimes related to fires, MCL 750.240 et seq.; crimes related to explosives and bombs, MCL 750.200 et seq.; explosives act, MCL 29.41 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE CODE 

Sec. 22-19. - Adoption. 
    The International Fire Code 2006 and any accumulative supplements, and all codes, standards, and recommended practices adopted by the National Fire Protection Association and the state fire protection code as it may be amended from time to time, as well as any administrative rules and policies promulgated in relation thereto, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference herein. In the event of conflict among the above-adopted codes, standards and recommended practices, the most restrictive regulations shall apply and shall be enforced by the authority with jurisdiction. 
(Code 1997, § 38-31; Ord. No. 782, 1-6-2003) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 22-20. - Authority to enforce fire related provisions of building code. 
(a)  The fire code shall be enforced by the director of public safety. In addition, in recognition of the fact that the state-approved building codes generally contain fire safety related regulations, thereby creating overlapping jurisdiction of the building official and the director of public safety, the director of public safety is hereby given authority to enforce the fire safety regulations set forth within the state approved building code. 
(b)  Whenever the terms "code official" and "department of fire prevention" are used in the fire code adopted by this article, they shall be held to mean the director of public safety and such personnel as may be designated by the director of public safety for the enforcement of the fire code. 
(Code 1997, § 38-32; Ord. No. 782, 1-6-2003) 
Sec. 22-21. - Revisions to code. 
    The following sections of the 2006 edition of the International Fire Code are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the City of Grosse Pointe Woods, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
Section 109.3 Violation penalties. The following penalties apply: 
(a)  First offense. Persons who violate a provision of this code, or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this code, or who erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of approved construction documents or directive of a code official, or of a permit or certificate used under this code, shall be responsible for a civil infraction, as defined by MCL 257.6a and MCL 257.6b, and shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $250.00 plus court costs. 
(b)  Second offense. Persons who violate a provision of this code or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this code, or who erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, or of a permit or certificate used under this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 plus court costs, or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Abatement of violation. (See Section 109.3.1.) 
Section 111.4. Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a separate offense subject to the violation penalties found in Section 109.3. 
(Code 1997, § 38-34; Ord. No. 782, 1-6-2003) 
Sec. 22-22. - Indemnification of enforcing official. 
    No fire department official enforcing these regulations or a designee shall be liable for the cost of damages incurred as a result of enforcement of any provision of this code or enforcement of measures necessary to insure the safety of this city and its populace. Such costs shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or operator of the property, equipment, vehicle or vessel causing or contributing to dangerous or hazardous conditions including pollution and potential pollution of the environment. 
(Code 1997, § 38-35; Ord. No. 782, 1-6-2003) 
Sec. 22-23. - Open burning. 
    The provisions found in section 307 (Open Burning) and section 308 (Open Flames) are hereby adopted with the following modifications: 
(1)  The use of portable outdoor fire pits and chiminea is allowed as an approved container provided: 
a.  The approved container is at least 15 feet from any structure, including a deck, garage or storage building. For purposes of this subsection, a deck is defined as a structure constructed of wood or other flammable material and does not include a deck constructed of cement, flagstone, bluestone or other impervious nonflammable material. 
b.  The fire must be constantly attended by at least one adult until the fire is completely extinguished. 
c.  At least one fire extinguisher or other equipment such as sand, water barrel, garden hose or water truck shall be available for immediate utilization. 
d.  The use of these approved containers remains subject to section 307.2.2 prohibiting offensive or objectionable smoke, spark, or odor emissions when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous as determined by the public safety department. 
e.  The approved container must rest on an impervious, nonflammable base. 
f.  Burning of construction material, demolition waste, furniture, appliances, tires, hazardous materials, treated or painted wood and plastic is prohibited. 
(2)  The use of dug out or below grade fire pits and bonfires used for any purpose as defined by section 307.3.1, is expressly prohibited. 
(Code 1997, § 38-36; Ord. No. 782, 1-6-2003) 
State Law reference- Open burning of leaves and grass clippings, MCL 324.11522. 
Secs. 22-24-22-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE CONTROL 

Sec. 22-50. - Authority of officials of department of public safety at fires and other emergencies. 
    The department of public safety official, or duly authorized representative, as may be in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency involving the protection of life or property, is empowered to direct such operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any suspected or reported fires, gas leaks or other hazardous conditions or situations, or to take any other action necessary in the reasonable performance of their duty. The department of public safety official may prohibit any person, vehicle or object from approaching the scene and may remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle or object which may impede or interfere with the operations of the department of public safety. The department of public safety official may remove or cause to be removed any person, vehicle or object from hazardous areas. All persons ordered to leave a hazardous area shall do so immediately and shall not reenter the area until authorized to do so by the department of public safety official. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-1; Code 1997, § 38-61) 
State Law reference- Obstructing, endangering or disobeying firefighters, MCL 750.241. 
Sec. 22-51. - Boarding or tampering with emergency vehicles or equipment. 
    A person shall not, without proper authorization from the department of public safety official in charge of such department of public safety emergency equipment, cling to, attach himself to, climb upon or into, board or swing upon any department of public safety emergency vehicle, whether the vehicle is in motion or at rest. He shall not sound the siren, horn, bell or other sound-producing device thereon, or manipulate or tamper with or attempt to manipulate or tamper with any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, brakes or pumps or any equipment or protective clothing on or a part of any department of public safety emergency vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-8; Code 1997, § 38-68) 
State Law reference- Destruction of fire department property, MCL 750.377b. 
Sec. 22-52. - Damaging emergency vehicle; injuring personnel of department of public safety. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, deface or attempt or conspire to damage or deface any department of public safety emergency vehicle at any time. It is also unlawful to injure, attempt to injure or conspire to injure department of public safety personnel while they are performing departmental duties. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-9; Code 1997, § 38-69) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.241, 750.377b. 
Sec. 22-53. - Blocking fire hydrant or fire connection. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful to obscure from view, damage, or deface, obstruct or restrict the access to any fire hydrant or any department of public safety fire connection for the pressurization of fire suppression systems, including fire hydrants and department of public safety fire connections that are located on public or private streets and access lanes, or on private property. 
(b)  Removal of obstructions by city. If, upon the expiration of the time mentioned in a notice of violation, obstructions or encroachments are not removed, the department of public safety official shall proceed to remove the obstruction or encroachment. Costs incurred in the performance of necessary work shall be paid from the city treasury on certificate of the department of public safety official and with the approval of the department of public safety chief administrative official. The legal authority of the city shall institute appropriate action for the recovery of such costs. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-11; Code 1997, § 38-71) 
State Law reference- Parking near fire hydrant, MCL 257.6741)(d). 
Sec. 22-54. - Permit required for use of fire hydrants. 
    A person shall not use or operate any fire hydrant intended for use of the department of public safety for fire suppression purposes unless such person first secures a permit for such use from the department of public safety official and the water company having jurisdiction. This section shall not apply to the use of such hydrants by a person employed by and authorized to make such use by city employees. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-12; Code 1997, § 38-72) 
Sec. 22-55. - Obstructing, removing or tampering with fire suppression equipment; maintenance of fire suppression equipment. 
    A person shall not obstruct, remove, tamper with or otherwise disturb any fire hydrant or fire appliance required to be installed or maintained under the provisions of the fire code, except for the purpose of extinguishing fire, training or testing purposes, recharging or making necessary repairs or when permitted by the department of public safety official. Whenever a fire appliance is removed as permitted under this section, it shall be replaced or reinstalled as soon as the purpose for which it was removed has been accomplished. Defective and nonapproved fire appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as directed by the department of public safety official. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-13; Code 1997, § 38-73) 
State Law reference- Destruction of fire department property, MCL 750.377b. 
Sec. 22-56. - Sale of defective fire extinguishers; exemption. 
(a)  Prohibited. A person shall not sell, trade, load or give away any form, type or kind of fire extinguisher which: 
(1)  Is not approved by the department of public safety official; 
(2)  Is not in proper working order; or 
(3)  The contents of which do not meet the requirements of the department of public safety official. 
(b)  Exemption. The requirements of this section shall not apply to the sale, trade or exchange of obsolete or damaged equipment for junk when the units are permanently disfigured or marked with a permanent sign identifying the unit as junk. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-14; Code 1997, § 38-74) 
Sec. 22-57. - Street obstructions. 
    No person shall erect, construct, place or maintain any bumps, fences, gates, chains, bars, pipes, wood or metal horses or any other type of obstruction in or on any street within the boundaries of the city. The term "street," as used in this section, shall mean any roadway accessible to the public for vehicular traffic, including but not limited to private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets and highways within the boundaries of the city. Temporary barricades may be erected with permission of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4-15; Code 1997, § 38-75) 
Chapter 24 - FRANCHISES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MICHIGAN CONSOLIDATED GAS COMPANY 

Sec. 24-19. - Grant of a nonexclusive gas franchise; consent. 
    Subject to all the terms and conditions mentioned in this chapter, consent is hereby given to Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, a corporation organized under the laws of the state (the "company"), and to its successors and assigns, to lay, maintain, operate and use natural gas pipes, mains, conductors, service pipes and other necessary equipment (facilities) in the dedicated public highways, streets, alleys, (public rights-of-way) in the city. A nonexclusive franchise is hereby granted to the company, its successors and assigns, to transact a local business in said city for the purpose of conveying natural gas into and through and supplying and selling natural gas in the city and all other matters incidental thereto. The company and its contractors and subcontractors shall maintain the company's facilities in reasonable and safe condition. Any easements over or under private property necessary for the construction or operation of MichCon's system shall be arranged and paid for by the company. Any easements required for property owned by the city other than public rights-of-way shall be separately negotiated with the city. The city shall be under no obligation to grant such easements. 
(Code 1997, § 39-41; Ord. No. 726, § 87-1, 7-6-1998) 
Sec. 24-20. - Gas service and extension of system. 
    If the provisions and conditions herein contained are accepted by the company, as provided in section 24-24, then the company shall furnish gas to applicants residing therein in accordance with applicable law, rules and regulations; and provided further that such initial installation and any extensions shall be subject to the main extension provisions, the area expansion program provisions (if and where applicable), and other applicable provisions now or from time to time hereafter contained in the company's rules and regulations for gas service as filed with the state public service commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction. 
(Code 1997, § 39-42; Ord. No. 726, § 87-2, 7-6-1998) 
Sec. 24-21. - Use of streets and other rights-of-way. 
(a)  Obstruction of public rights-of-way; maintenance and repair after excavation; liability. The company and its contractors and subcontractors shall not unduly burden or interfere with the present or future use of any of the public rights-of-way. The company, its successors and assigns, shall not unnecessarily obstruct the passage of any streets or other public rights-of-way within the city and shall at its sole cost and expense within ten working days or such additional time as specified by the director of public service, in accordance with this Code and standards established by the city's engineer, after making an opening or excavation, repair the same and leave it in as good as or better condition as before the opening or excavation was made. The company and its contractors and subcontractors shall use due care at all times in exercising the privileges herein contained. In the event that the company and its contractors and subcontractors fail to make such repair within the time specified by the city, the city shall be entitled to complete the repair and the company shall pay the costs to the city for such repair. The company shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the city and its officers, agents and employees from and against all charges, costs, claims, damages, losses, liabilities, obligations, expenses, judgments, penalties and proceedings of whatever nature (including, without limitation, actual fees and expenses of attorneys, expert witnesses, and consultants), arising from the company's exercise of its rights pursuant to this article, whether by the company or by the company's contractors and subcontractors. 
(b)  Emergency repairs; issuance of permit. Except in emergencies, no streets or other public rights-of-way shall be opened for the laying of trunk lines or lateral mains, except upon application to the city and other authority having jurisdiction in the premises, stating the nature of the proposed work and the route. Where emergency repairs become necessary, the company agrees to notify the city's public safety department of such repairs as soon as practical. Upon receipt of such application, it shall be the duty of the city and, such other authority as may have jurisdiction, to issue a permit to the company to do the work proposed if such work meets with the standards and codes of the city. 
(1)  Relocation of facilities. The company, its contractors and subcontractors shall, at the company's own cost and expense, protect, support, disconnect, relocate in or remove from the public rights-of-way and facilities when required to do so by the city due to street or other public excavation, construction, repair grading, regrading or traffic conditions, the installation of sewers, drains, water pipes or municipally-owned facilities of any kind; the vacation, construction or relocation of streets; or other public improvements by a unit of government. 
(2)  Vacation. Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, if a public right-of-way is vacated, eliminated, discontinued or closed, the city's consent to any such vacation, elimination or discontinuance shall be conditioned upon the reservation of an easement in such public way for the benefit of the company. The city and the company may agree in writing to a different resolution in any particular case. 
(3)  High pressure lines. In the event that the city or its contractors and subcontractors are working within the public rights-of-way in the vicinity of a gas line having pressure of 250 pounds per square inch or more, the company shall, at its sole expense, furnish at least one company representative who shall remain at the work site or remain on call during the work and who shall identify for the city or its contractors the location of such high pressure gas line and how to avoid damage to or interference with such high pressure gas line. 
(4)  Traffic control. For all work which may disturb the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, the franchisee shall employ roadway closure or partial closure practices as delineated in the state manual of uniform traffic control devices and the standards established by the director of public safety and/or public service. 
(5)  As builts. The company shall keep accurate, complete and current maps and records of its facilities. The company shall furnish the city with access to its "as-built" maps and records through electronic (e.g. MARS) or other means as the parties may mutually agree. If the access is through electronic means, the company shall furnish, at no cost to the city, such connecting hardware and computer software which will enable the city to access the company's records in a timely manner. The company shall participate in and be a member of the "MISS DIG" utility notification program provided by MCL 460.701-460.718 or subsequent state statute. 
(6)  Compliance with law. The company and its contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to all applicable laws, ordinances or regulations in the course of constructing, installing, operating or maintaining the facilities in the city. Without limitation, the company shall comply with the latest edition of the following if applicable to the company of its facilities: 
a.  The state gas safety code. 
b.  The American National Standards Institute ANSI B-109.1, Standard for Gas Displacement Meters. 
c.  The American National Standards Institute Z223.1, National Fuel Gas Code. 
d.  The National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 59, LP Gases and Utility Plants. 
e.  The National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 58, Storage and Handling, Liquefied Petroleum Gases. 
f.  The National Fire Association Standard No. 59A, Production, Storage and Handling, Liquefied Natural Gas. 
g.  General Rules of the Construction Code Commission. 
h.  The company and its contractors and subcontractors shall comply with all city zoning and land use restrictions as may exist or may hereafter be amended. 
(7)  Preconstruction meetings. A company representative shall attend all preconstruction meetings conducted by the city in connection with any public improvement projects in the public rights-of-way in the city. The company representative shall notify the city and its contractors of any conditions of the company's facilities which may affect the project and the company shall make provisions necessary to prevent the company's facilities (or their condition) from delaying or otherwise interfering with the project. 
(8)  Pavement cut coordination/additional fees. 
a.  The company shall coordinate its construction program and all other work in the public rights-of-way with the city's program for street construction, rebuilding, resurfacing and repair (collectively "street resurfacing"), which is planned several years in advance. The company shall meet with the city at least twice per year to this end. The goals of such coordination shall be to require the company to conduct all known work in the public rights-of-way in conjunction with or immediately prior to any construction, rebuilding, resurfacing or repair planned by the city, and to prevent the public rights-of-way from being disturbed by the company for a period of years after they have been constructed, rebuilt, resurfaced or repaired. 
b.  In addition to any other fees or payments required by this article, except in the case of emergencies, or if requested by the city, the company shall pay to the city the sum of $1,250.00 for each 50 feet, or portion thereof, cut into or excavation of any public rights-of-way which was constructed, rebuilt, resurfaced or repaired within 24 months prior to such cut or excavation. This fee is in addition to and not in lieu of the obligation to restore the public rights-of-way as set forth hereinabove. The company shall, in addition, pay all fees as established by council resolution as adopted from time to time as well as any fees required by other ordinances of the city. 
(9)  Removal of facilities upon revocation or expiration. Within 90 days after the franchise expires or is revoked, surrendered or otherwise terminated and is not reestablished, the company will elect, and will notify the city in writing of its election to: 
a.  Remove its personal property, and equipment from the streets, avenues, lanes, alleys, bridges, public highways and other public places in the city, at its own expense; 
b.  Sell or otherwise dispose of such personal property; 
c.  Abandon such property in place, consistent with the state gas safety code or other applicable gas safety standards; or 
d.  In the event the company elects removal, within 24 months after receiving all required permits and other approvals, remove all such personal property in accordance with such permits and approvals, and restore such streets, avenues, lanes, alleys, bridges, public highways and other public places so as to conform as nearly as practicable with the then current condition of same at the date of such restoration. In the event the company elects sale or disposal, it shall use all diligent and reasonable means to locate a purchaser and consummate the transaction on commercially acceptable terms and conditions; provided that any such purchaser shall, prior to operation of any gas utility business, obtain a franchise from the city to conduct same. 
(Code 1997, § 39-43; Ord. No. 726, § 87-3, 7-6-1998) 
Sec. 24-22. - Standards and conditions of service; rules, regulations and rates. 
    The company is now under the jurisdiction of the state public service commission to the extent provided by statute; and the rates to be charged for gas, and the standards and conditions of service and operation hereunder, shall be the same as set forth in the company's schedule of rules, regulations and rates as applicable in the several cities, villages and townships in which the company is now rendering gas service, or as shall hereafter be validly prescribed for the city under the orders, rules, and regulations of the state public service commission or other authority having jurisdiction in the premises. 
(Code 1997, § 39-44; Ord. No. 726, § 87-4, 7-6-1998) 
Sec. 24-23. - Franchise assignment, sale, change of control. 
(a)  Transfer. The company shall not assign or transfer any of its rights under this agreement in whole or in part, voluntarily, involuntarily or by operation of law, including by merger or consolidation, substantial change in the ownership or control of company's business, or by other means, without the prior written consent of the city. The city will not unreasonably withhold its consent. 
(b)  City expenses. The company shall pay and/or reimburse the city for any actual costs incurred by the city due to any proposed transfer, including whether such transfer is approved with conditions, or denied. 
(Code 1997, § 39-45; Ord. No. 726, § 87-5, 7-6-1998) 
Sec. 24-24. - Effective date; term of franchise ordinance; acceptance by company. 
    The provisions of this article took effect ten days following the date of publication of the ordinance from which this article was derived, and shall continue in effect for a period of ten years thereafter, subject to revocation at the will of the city at any time during said ten-year period; provided, however, that when this article shall become effective the city clerk shall deliver to the company a certified copy of the ordinance from which this article was derived accompanied by written evidence of publication and recording thereof as required by law, and the company shall, 60 days after receiving the above mentioned documents, file with the city clerk its written acceptance of the conditions and provisions hereof. 
(Code 1997, § 39-46; Ord. No. 726, § 87-6, 7-6-1998) 
Sec. 24-25. - City Charter. 
    The franchise granted by this article is subject to all terms, conditions and limitations as set forth in the city Charter and city ordinances. 
(Code 1997, § 39-47; Ord. No. 726, § 87-7, 7-6-1998) 
Chapter 26 - LAND DEVELOPMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Legal basis. 
    This article should be read in conjunction with the subdivisions chapter (chapter 40), zoning chapter (chapter 50), buildings and building regulations chapter (chapter 8), environment chapter (chapter 20), streets, sidewalks and other public places chapter (chapter 38), traffic and vehicles chapter (chapter 42), and utilities chapter (chapter 44). 
(Code 1997, § 48-1; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrator means the person appointed by the council as city administrator. 
    Building inspector means the person appointed by the city administrator to enforce the building codes of the city. 
    Building service sewer (drainage water) means any drainage water pipe extension from a building foundation drain outlet (located five feet outside of a building or dwelling unit) to a public stormwater drain or combined sewer. 
    Building service sewer (wastewater) means the sewer extension from a building drain outlet point (located five feet outside of a building or a dwelling unit) to a point of connection with a public sanitary sewer or combined sewer. 
    City engineer means the staff registered professional engineer or the consulting engineer representing the city in this position. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer, together with appurtenances, that intentionally carries both wastewater and stormwater. 
    Director of public services means the person appointed by the city administrator to manage the department of public works. 
    Ditch and drainage swale mean an open channel used to transport water, groundwater, surface water runoff, or drainage water from any source. 
    Drainage facilities and drainage water facilities mean any storm sewers, combined sewers, lakes, ponds, streams, rivers or storm drains, including facilities designated as county drains, that receive water from lands owned by more than one owner. 
    Foundation drain service pipe means a conveyance pipe that receives only foundation drain groundwater seepage, exclusive of directly and intentionally introduced surface water runoff. 
    Natural outlet means any drainage water outlet, including storm drains and sewers into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Open drain means an open channel used to transport water, groundwater, surface water runoff or drainage water from any source. 
    Private wastewater disposal system means a septic tank with subsurface soil absorption facilities, wastewater treatment facilities, or similar methods of wastewater disposal that may be approvable by the county health department and/or the state department of environmental quality (DEQ). 
    Public sanitary sewer means a sanitary sewer intended to be located in public easements or public rights-of-way that collects (or is intended to collect) wastewater from more than one user or premises and that is required to receive the approval and issuance of a construction permit from the municipal wastewater control section of the DEQ. 
    Public sewer and public drain mean a common sewer or drain that collects drainage water from more than one user or premises and is controlled by the city public works department or another governmental agency. 
    Sanitary sewer and wastewater sewer mean a sewer, together with appurtenances, that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater and surface water runoff that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Sewage force main and force main mean a wastewater conveyance pipe which carries wastewater under pressure. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater and/or drainage water. 
    Stormwater detention, unless otherwise stated, means an underground stormwater storage facility which is designed to detain stormwater and shall not include wastewater or combined sewage. 
    Stormwater drain, storm drain and storm sewer mean a watercourse or a sewer intended for the conveyance of water, groundwater, surface water runoff, drainage water or other water from any source exclusive of intentionally admitted wastewater. 
    Stormwater inlet and catchbasin structure mean a structure designed and constructed to intentionally admit surface water runoff, drainage water or other water from any source exclusive of intentionally admitted wastewater. 
    Surface water runoff and stormwater mean that part of rainfall or melting snowfall that reaches the sewer as runoff from natural land surfaces, building roofs or pavements. 
    Underdrain pipe means a geotextile-wrapped perforated pipe installed underground for the specific purpose of lowering a high groundwater condition or draining a granular subbase by receiving groundwater seepage and conveying it to a stormwater drain. Farm drain tile is not underdrain pipe. 
    Unpolluted water and drainage water mean water of a quality equal to, or better than, the effluent criteria currently in effect (as specified by the DEQ), or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards. 
    Wastewater and sewage mean the spent water of a community, including liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater, and surface water runoff that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Wastewater treatment works and sewage treatment plant mean facilities for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. 
    Watercourse means a natural or artificial open channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1997, § 48-2; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-3. - Site grading and drainage water collection and disposal systems. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to change the drainage pattern of any land by excavating, grading or filling without first obtaining a permit for construction from the city. Each site shall be graded for the purpose of directing surface water runoff to appropriate drainage water collection and disposal systems as is necessary, and same shall be done in a manner which will not cause drainage water from the site to flow onto adjacent land nor obstruct the flow of existing drainage from adjacent properties. Drainage water collection and disposal systems shall be provided to collect surface water runoff and/or building foundation drain groundwater seepage. The drainage water collection system shall consist of enclosed storm sewers throughout the project. An extension of the storm sewer system shall be provided to furnish an outlet for foundation drain service pipes for each building. The collected drainage water shall be conveyed to a point of disposal that shall be a public stormwater drain. 
(b)  When, in the opinion of the city engineer and/or the county public works commissioner, there is inadequate drainage water outlet capacity, and an adequate drainage water outlet cannot be reasonably engineered and constructed, the developer shall install an adequate underground stormwater detention basin with controlled outlet facilities to limit the rate of flow of drainage water from the site. Final approval of any plans, which include an underground stormwater detention basin, shall be conditioned upon an operation and maintenance special assessment district agreement with the city. The following shall apply: 
(1)  Underground stormwater detention basins on private developments, where ownership will remain consolidated over an extended period of time, such as industrial sites, shopping centers, apartment complexes, etc., shall remain in private ownership, subject to city review as to size, design and proper operation. Maintenance and liability shall remain with the property owner. 
(2)  Underground stormwater detention basins serving predominantly single-family areas or platted subdivision may be dedicated to the city for ownership and maintenance, subject to the criteria established herein and subject to case-by-case review and approval by the planning commission and the city council. Such development shall be required to file a standing stormwater facility operation and maintenance special assessment district agreement prior to final approval. 
(3)  Underground stormwater detention basins shall not be required for improvements to existing single-family residential establishments or for existing subdivision lots where the proposed house does not substantially increase the volume of stormwater runoff. 
(4)  Locations for underground stormwater detention basins shall be shown on the site plan, the engineering plan, the preliminary plat, and the final plats, as applicable. 
(Code 1997, § 48-3; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-4. - Wastewater collection and disposal system. 
(a)  All developments shall be serviced by a separate wastewater collection and disposal system acceptable to the city. A site plan or a preliminary subdivision plat submitted to the city shall be accompanied by data describing the type of wastewater collection and disposal system that is to be provided for the development. 
(b)  For all developments, the developer shall provide sanitary sewers to service each proposed building site and shall connect same to a public wastewater disposal system. Individual existing single-family residential and duplex family residential sites without access to public sanitary sewer shall locate the public combined sewer and connect thereto. All wastewater disposal systems shall be designed in a manner acceptable to the city engineer, the county department of public services, and the state department of environmental quality. 
(Code 1997, § 48-4; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-5. - Residential plot plan and site plan submittals. 
(a)  Topographical survey requirements. For all plot plans and acreage/nonplatted parcels, a full topographic survey is required. Surveys require location and description of all underground utilities; rims and inverts of all manholes, catchbasins and stop boxes; north arrow; property corners, irons, monuments and fences; a 50-foot grid of existing elevations to 100 feet offsite (including lot corners); existing structures with finished grade and finished floor elevations of all structures on adjacent lots; all vegetation and trees on adjacent lots and lot to be developed; and the public drainage course to which the proposed lot will drain. Elevations must be corrected to conform to the North American Vertical Datum (NAVD)/city datum with a minimum of two benchmarks being depicted on the plans. This list is not intended to be all inclusive. 
(b)  Grading and drainage. 
(1)  Plan. A grading plan is required with all plot plan submittals and must include the following information: 
a.  Proposed elevations at all lot corners, along side lot lines immediately adjacent to existing and/or proposed structures, in swales and ditches at regular intervals not to exceed 50 feet, and at all proposed building corners. 
b.  The plan must contain sufficient information to detail the drainage of the lot. All site drainage must be directed to a public drain. If no public drain is immediately available or adjacent to the site, it will be the responsibility of the site developer to extend drainage to the site from an approved outlet. When insufficient depth exists to service a site, it may be necessary for the developer to deepen the existing drain to service the site. 
(2)  Elevation. Existing elevations at property lines shall be met by new construction. In no case shall on-site drainage be directed to an adjacent site or shall existing offsite drainage patterns be interrupted. 
(3)  Slopes. Slopes of swales on site shall be 0.50 percent or greater. 
(4)  Storm drainage. Storm drains shall be designed to conform to section 26-3, Site grading and drainage water collection and disposal. On site storm sewers, when servicing only the parcel being developed, are to be a minimum of eight-inch diameter and are to be constructed of minimum schedule 40 PVC or SDR 23.5 ABS, or equal. 
(5)  Pipes. Minimum pipe slopes shall be sufficient to provide a velocity of 2.5 fps or greater. When servicing more than one parcel, the pipe shall be a minimum eight-inch diameter and be constructed in a 12-foot wide easement dedicated to the city. A larger pipe or easement may be necessary as determined by the city engineer. 
(6)  System compliance. All the components of the stormwater system, including rims and grates shall be in accordance with the current city storm sewer detail sheets. 
(c)  Utilities. 
(1)  Sanitary sewer. A six-inch diameter sanitary sewer lead shall be provided for each residence leading to a sanitary sewer. The lead shall have a minimum slope of one percent and shall be constructed of a minimum schedule 40 PVC or SDR 23.5 ABS. No more than one single-family residence shall utilize an individual lead. 
(2)  Storm sewer. A sump pump lead shall be provided for each residential structure so equipped. The lead shall be a minimum three-inch diameter and be constructed of a minimum schedule 40 PVC or SDR 23.5 ABS. The lead must outlet to an approved public drain. 
(Code 1997, § 48-5; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-6. - General plan. 
(a)  Sewers in easements shall be located at least three feet away from parcel or lot boundary lines. A variation to this requirement can be granted by the city engineer upon presentation of data indicating another location is best suited. 
(b)  Superimposed on a general plan of the site shall be a topographic survey and contour lines of the project area, including the area at least 100 feet outside of the project area. Where the contour of the land is such that contour lines do not provide enough information to evaluate a proposed grading and drainage scheme, spot elevations taken on a 50-foot grid shall be shown instead. Contour lines shall be shown at intervals as follows: 
(1)  Where the general slope of the land is one percent or less, the interval shall be one foot. 
(2)  Where the general slope of the land is more than one percent, but less than five percent, the interval shall be two feet. 
(3)  Where the general slope of the land is five percent or greater, the interval shall be five feet. 
(c)  All sewers and those water mains having a diameter of 16 inches or greater shall be indicated in profiles. It shall be the responsibility of the design engineer to ascertain that the depth of the storm sewer (or storm drain) does not interfere with the building service sewers crossing the storm sewer. Profiles shall indicate the size of pipe, class of pipe, slope of the utility, and control elevations of the utility. The existing and proposed grade lines shall be shown along the profile view of each utility. The profile shall show all points where utilities cross one another with elevations for each utility calculated and shown. The designer shall maintain a one-foot vertical clearance between underground utilities. Water mains shall have 18-inch vertical clearance from other underground utilities. All engineering information shall be presented in a clear and concise manner as determined by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 48-6; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-7. - State civil engineer approval. 
    All plans shall be signed and sealed by a civil engineer registered to practice in the state. 
(Code 1997, § 48-7; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Secs. 26-8-26-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORMWATER COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SYSTEM 

Sec. 26-33. - Plan requirements. 
    All sets of plans which include plans for storm sewers shall include the current city storm sewer detail sheets which shall be considered an inseparable part of the plans when said plans are approved. 
(Code 1997, § 48-31; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-34. - Site grading. 
    A site grading and stormwater collection and disposal plan is required for all developments. If the building site is in a subdivision or other project for which a general site grading plan has been submitted and approved, no separate grading plan or permit will be required. An enclosed storm drainage system shall be designed for all land development projects. If there are any upstream watershed drainage areas which need to be drained through the site under design consideration, sufficient capacity shall be provided to take fully developed upstream watershed drainage areas. Surface water runoff from the proposed improved site shall not be drained on adjacent property. 
(1)  Each development shall have an overall grading plan showing grades for side yards, rear yards, sidewalks, and catchbasins. Storm sewers, building finish floor grades, brick ledge (ground) grades and direction of surface drainage flow shall be shown. 
(2)  Rear yard storm sewers shall be required in all subdivisions and residential condominium developments. Catchbasins (two-inch minimum diameter) shall be placed at every other lot corner so that every dwelling directly abuts a catchbasin in at least one corner. All catchbasin outlet sewers shall extend in side lot easements to the public storm sewer in the road right-of-way. 
(3)  Any required rear yard and side yard drain easements shall be a minimum of 12 feet wide. The city engineer shall require additional easement width when sewer size depth, soils or other conditions warrant a wider easement. 
(4)  Site grading for all building sites shall be reviewed to determine that proposed and/or actual site grading is proper and that drainage from land lying upstream is not obstructed and that downstream properties will not be diversely effected by runoff from the property under design consideration. 
(5)  Before a certificate of occupancy for any building is issued, the building inspector shall approve the final site grading and drainage for each building; and/or the building inspector shall require that a survey, drawing, and certificate done by a registered professional engineer or registered land surveyor be furnished by the developer indicating that the work has been done in conformity to the approved site grading and drainage plan. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, modify or obstruct the flow of drainage water across any property in any manner different from the approved plan. 
(7)  During periods of the year when weather conditions make site grading work unfeasible, a temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued, subject to the furnishing of a satisfactory bond, letter of credit or cash deposit in an amount determined by the city engineer or building inspector and approved by the city administrator, guaranteeing the completion of the work when weather conditions permit. 
(8)  Any property owner claiming to be aggrieved by any site grading work, or decision of the administrator relative to site grading of a parcel of property, shall have the right to appeal the decision of the administrator to the city council. Such an appeal must be requested in writing, stating fully and clearly the reasons for the request and including any supplemental information and data that may aid in the analysis of the proposed request. Written notice of the date and time of the hearing shall be delivered to the owner of the property on which the grading work has, is or will be performed. In conjunction with a determination on the appeal, the council has express authority to assess actual costs against the owner of the property on which the grading work has, is or will be performed. The amount of the filing fee will be reimbursed to the applicant in the case of a successful appeal. 
(Code 1997, § 48-32; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-35. - Slope requirements. 
(a)  The fall of the land away from any building shall be a minimum of six inches in the first 25 feet. From this elevation, the land shall slope to a drainage water collection swale at a minimum slope of one foot in 100 feet (one percent). 
(b)  The maximum slope of the land for the site shall not exceed one foot in four feet as provided in chapter 50, zoning. Sodded swale or ditch slopes shall be a maximum slope of one foot vertically and four feet horizontally. 
(Code 1997, § 48-33; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-36. - Soil erosion and sedimentation control. 
    Adequate soil erosion and sedimentation control measures shall be specified on the plans (and followed during construction) to conform to the requirements of the soil erosion and sedimentation control laws, Part 91 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.9101 et seq.). A soil erosion permit shall be acquired by the developer from the building inspector prior to issuance of a construction permit. 
(Code 1997, § 48-34; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-37. - Basement and foundation requirements. 
    All buildings having foundation drains shall direct the flow of drainage water from such foundation drains into a storm sewer or a storm drain by means of an underground enclosed conveyance pipe four-inch diameter (minimum). No building permit shall be issued for any building having a basement without a building service sewer (drainage water) with drainage to a storm sewer or storm drain. A sump and pump shall be required in basements that do not have an adequate storm sewer outlet. Pump size shall be adequate to carry intercepted groundwater. 
(Code 1997, § 48-35; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-38. - Building runoff. 
    Drainage water runoff from building roofs shall be piped to a point five feet away from the outside walls of any building. Drainage water from building roofs shall not be directly connected to the storm sewer system. No drainage water runoff shall be allowed on adjacent property. Drainage water, sump pump water and/or groundwater shall not be discharged directly to the combined sewer system without written approval by the city engineer and concurrence of city administrator. 
(Code 1997, § 48-36; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-39. - Drainage swales. 
    The longitudinal grade of any drainage swale shall not be less than 0.5 foot per 100 feet (0.5 percent). The maximum distance drainage water shall travel in a drainage swale without an intercepting yard catchbasin shall be 300 feet. Not more than 100 feet of drainage water travel shall be upstream of an angle point (deflection angle 45 degrees or greater) in the drainage swale. Planned final grade elevations shall be indicated on the plans at a maximum spacing of 50 feet. 
(Code 1997, § 48-37; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-40. - Drainage swale construction. 
    Where required by the city engineer, a six-inch diameter geotextile-wrapped perforated drainage pipe shall be provided for drainage with said pipe trench being backfilled entirely with pea gravel up to within four inches of the grade line of the swale. 
(Code 1997, § 48-38; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-41. - Drainage system design. 
(a)  Stormwater runoff drainage systems shall be designed for a ten-year storm by means of the rational method formula: Q=CIA; where Q is the peak rate of runoff in cubic feet per second, A is the area in acres, C is the coefficient of runoff for the drainage area and I is the average rainfall intensity in inches per hour. The rainfall intensity shall be determined by the formula: I=175/(T+25); where T is the time of concentration equal to the time required for a drop of water to run from the most remote point of the watershed to the point for which runoff is being estimated. In most instances, an initial T equal to 15 min. for residential areas can be used. Use T=10 min. in other land use areas. The developer's engineer shall use judgment in arriving at proper imperviousness factors, but, in general, the following factors are acceptable minimums: 
Lawn areas 0.20 Pavement and roof areas 0.90 Overall area of single-family subdivision 0.35 Overall area of multiple housing development 0.55 Overall area of commercial development 0.90 Overall area of industrial development 0.90  
(b)  The city engineer reserves the right to assign lower times of concentration and higher "C" factors if the perviousness of the proposed project warrants. 
(c)  Where possible, provide a minimum of three feet of cover from the top of finish road or earth grade to the top of pipe of any storm sewer. It will be acceptable to allow the hydraulic gradient to be above the top of the sewer pipe, but in no case shall the hydraulic gradient exceed one foot below the rim elevation. The design elevation of the hydraulic gradient profile shall be indicated on the sewer profile view. Nonsubmerged drain systems shall be designed to operate with the water surface elevation at or below the 0.8 rise level. 
(Code 1997, § 48-39; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-42. - Manhole and catchbasin requirements. 
(a)  Access manholes (four-foot minimum diameter) shall be provided along the storm sewer at every change of pipe size, change of grade or change of direction. However, the maximum spacing for storm sewer manholes shall be as follows: 
Diameter of Sewer 
(in inches) Absolute Maximum Manhole Spacing 
(in feet) 12 to 30  350 36 to 42  400 48  450 54 and 60  500 66 and larger  600  
Note: Height (rise) of arch and elliptical pipe shall be used as the criteria for manhole spacing. 
(b)  Manholes and catchbasins shall be constructed utilizing precast concrete segments or class A concrete block and mortar. 
(c)  Catchbasins shall not be constructed over a main sewer line to replace manholes. If a normal manhole location (outside of streets) coincides with a stormwater inlet structure location a catchbasin of adequate diameter may be used as a stormwater inlet structure in lieu of the manhole. 
(Code 1997, § 48-40; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-43. - Placement of catchbasins. 
(a)  An end section with prefabricated bar screen shall be installed on the end of all storm sewers 12 inches in diameter and larger which outlet into an open drain. Openings of the bar screen shall be no more than six inches on centers. 
(b)  In general, pavement type catchbasins shall be located as follows: 
(1)  At or near the radius return of street intersections (not in the path of sidewalks). 
(2)  At all low points in streets. 
(3)  At intermediate points along the street such that there is a maximum pavement drainage area per structure as follows: 
a.  Intercepting catchbasins: 10,000 S.F./C.B. 
b.  Low point catchbasins: 12,000 S.F./C.B. 
(c)  Yard type catchbasins shall be provided at all low points in drainage swales. Provide intercepting yard type catchbasins such that not more than 300 feet of swale drainage runs into any one catchbasin other than a low point catchbasin where 600 feet of drainage is allowed. 
(Code 1997, § 48-41; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-44. - Storm sewer extensions. 
    An extension of the storm sewer system shall be provided to furnish an outlet for foundation drain service pipe for any buildings not otherwise serviced; such extensions shall have a minimum diameter of six inches. 
(Code 1997, § 48-42; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-45. - Infiltration testing. 
    For every storm sewer project, there shall be indicated on the profile view a manhole with a 12-inch deep manhole sump to be used for testing for infiltration. This manhole generally shall be the first manhole upstream from the point of connection to the existing combined or storm sewer system. No storm sewer section having an infiltration rate, or an exfiltration rate, of more than 100 gallons per inch of pipe diameter per mile of pipe per 24-hour period shall be approved for connection to the city combined sewer system. A low pressure air test or televising may be required in lieu of an infiltration test as determined by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 48-43; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Secs. 26-46-26-63. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STORMWATER DETENTION SYSTEM 

Sec. 26-64. - Appropriation of detention basin and requirements. 
    The city engineer (based on existing sewer capacity, existing off-site sewer hydraulics, the increase of impervious surfaces, and surrounding site conditions) shall make a determination as to the adequacy of the existing storm sewer or combined sewer system. In the event it is determined the existing sewer system has inadequate capacity, the developer shall make necessary downstream drainage improvements or be required to install underground detention basins or reservoirs. If detention is deemed appropriate, the storage capacity of such detention basin shall be rated in acre-feet and shall contain a capacity as determined by the engineer, but in no case shall be less than two inches of water over the entire watershed area that drains into the detention basin. Discharge from the detention basin shall be at a controlled rate. Discharge rate shall not exceed 0.2 cubic feet per second (cfs) per acre without written approval by the city engineer. A discharge rate less than 0.2 cfs per acre may be required. The developer shall provide the field data as required by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 48-71; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-65. - Additional detention basin requirements. 
(a)  All stormwater detention must be below ground. Design storage in a parking lot is not acceptable. 
(b)  The design elevation for storage in the detention basin shall be below the rim of the lowest catchbasin draining into the detention basin. 
(c)  The bottom of the basin shall have a minimum grade of one percent. 
(d)  An overflow system shall be provided. The overflow system shall consist of additional storage volume in the parking lot, if applicable, and weir flow into the street. Depth of water in the parking lot shall not exceed six inches and all curbs must remain visible. 
(e)  Detention basins shall be designed to drain completely within 36 hours after a rain. 
(f)  Orifice restrictions shall be designed in accordance with the current city storm sewer detail sheets. 
(g)  In general, orifice restrictions should be designed with a four-inch diameter (or greater). In no case shall orifices be designed smaller than three inches in diameter. 
(h)  For basins with pumped outlets, a silt trap and bar screen shall be installed on the inlet pipe to the pump station. The screen clear opening shall be a maximum of two inches. 
(i)  Pumping stations for dewatering of the detention basins shall be reviewed and approved by the city engineer. 
(j)  In general, detention basins shall be privately owned and maintained. The owner shall be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the detention basin. 
(k)  The manhole where the orifice restriction and/or pump is located shall be designated as an inspection manhole to ensure that the orifice and/or pump is maintained to design specifications. This manhole shall be installed in a public utility easement by the owner at the owner's expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(l)  A signed maintenance agreement and approved plans for detention facilities and storm drainage facilities (which will not be owned and operated by the city), shall be in effect prior to city approval. The maintenance agreement requirements shall include an annual operating permit obtained from the city which will provide for annual inspections. The maintenance agreement requirement can be waived by the city administrator. 
(m)  For subdivision detention basins that will be owned and operated by the city, the developer and/or builder shall ensure adequate funds by creating a special assessment district to cover maintenance, operation and insurance liability costs for the basin. 
(Code 1997, § 48-72; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Secs. 26-66-26-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WASTEWATER COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SYSTEM 

Sec. 26-89. - Plan requirements. 
    All sets of plans which include plans for sanitary sewers shall include the current city sanitary sewer detail sheets which shall be considered an inseparable part of the plans when said plans are approved. 
(Code 1997, § 48-91; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-90. - Infiltration testing. 
    For every sanitary sewer project, there shall be indicated on the profile view a manhole with a 12-inch deep manhole sump to be used for testing for infiltration. This manhole generally shall be the first manhole upstream from the point of connection to the existing sanitary sewer system. No sanitary sewer section having an infiltration rate, or an exfiltration rate, of more than 100 gallons per inch of pipe diameter per mile of pipe per 24-hour period shall be approved for connection to the city sanitary sewer system. A low pressure air test or televising may be required in lieu of an infiltration test. 
(Code 1997, § 48-92; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-91. - Sewer size. 
    The minimum allowable size for public sanitary sewers shall be eight-inch diameter. The minimum size of building service sewers (wastewater) shall be six-inch diameter. Each condominium unit shall have a separate sanitary lead. Each unit in commercial, industrial, or office multiunit developments shall have a separate sanitary lead. Sanitary leads shall be constructed such that they do not cross the building envelope of another unit. An approved cleanout will be installed at the sewer right-of-way or easement line when the lead is extended to the premises. 
(Code 1997, § 48-93; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-92. - Gravity sewer slopes. 
(a)  The following table of acceptable slopes for sanitary sewers shall be adhered to:
