(b)  Gravity sewers shall be designed for a minimum velocity of two feet per second and a maximum of eight feet per second. Where sufficient depth is available, the extreme upstream run of sewer without the potential for future extension shall have the minimum slope increased to develop a design velocity of three feet per second. 
(Code 1997, § 48-94; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-93. - Sewage force mains. 
    Sanitary sewage force mains shall be designed for a minimum velocity of two feet per second and a maximum velocity of ten feet per second, unless otherwise approved. Force mains shall be shown in a profile view with grades and elevations indicated thereon. An air relief and cleanout assembly manhole shall be provided at high points. Access (cleanout assembly) manholes shall be provided along the force main at least every 600 feet. 
(Code 1997, § 48-95; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-94. - Building service sewers. 
    A building service sewer shall be indicated on the plans for each building in the project. Where sanitary sewers are planned along roadways, the building service sewers shall be extended across the roadways (to the right-of-way line) prior to paving. 
(Code 1997, § 48-96; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-95. - Manhole locations. 
    Manholes (four-foot minimum diameter) shall be provided along all sanitary sewers at: 
(1)  Points of horizontal deflection; 
(2)  Points where the size of sewer is changed; 
(3)  Points where the slope of the sewer is changed; 
(4)  At junctions with other sewer lines; 
(5)  At the upstream terminus of a sewer run; 
(6)  Along the sanitary sewer at other locations such that the maximum spacing between manholes shall not exceed 350 feet. 
(Code 1997, § 48-97; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-96. - Elevation adjustments. 
    At manholes, where size of sewers change, match 0.8 diameter elevation points of inlet and outlet sewer. At horizontal deflections in the sanitary sewer greater than 45 degrees, a minimum of 0.10 foot additional adjustment in grade elevation shall be provided to allow for loss of head. However, additional elevation adjustments may be made when conditions allow same; provided that, when the invert of any inlet sewer is more than 18 inches above the outlet sewer, an internal drop assembly shall be provided. External drop connections will not be permitted without written approval of the superintendent. 
(Code 1997, § 48-98; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-97. - Sewer location. 
    Sanitary sewers shall be located within a public street right-of-way or public easements adjacent to street right-of-way. Sanitary sewers shall not be located within rear lot easements, except in extremely unusual circumstances as determined by the city engineer. Where public sanitary sewers are located outside of public streets, they shall be placed in a recorded public utility easement that provides for unlimited access to the sanitary sewer for repairs, connections, and maintenance. The minimum acceptable width of easements for public sanitary sewers shall be 20 feet wide; except that, if adjacent and parallel to the public street, it may be reduced to 12 feet wide. 
(Code 1997, § 48-99; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-98. - Sewer depth. 
    The sanitary sewer trunk line shall be designed to have a minimum depth from finish grade elevation to top of sewer of 81/2 feet at local control points or nine feet at locations where the sewer grade is parallel to the road grade. All sewer mains shall be constructed at the maximum practicable depth to facilitate future extensions of the main. In no case shall collector sewers be built with less than five feet of cover. 
(Code 1997, § 48-100; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-99. - Infiltration plugs. 
    Each wye or terminus of building service sewer shall be plugged with an infiltration proof plug in accordance with current city standards. 
(Code 1997, § 48-101; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-100. - Pipes and joints. 
    The type of pipe and joints for sanitary sewers shall be in accordance with current city standards. 
(Code 1997, § 48-102; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-101. - Hazardous waste regulation. 
    The owner of commercial or industrial property serviced by a building sewer carrying hazardous or toxic wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city engineer. The manhole shall be installed in a public sewer or utility easement by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. The effluent shall meet the City of Detroit and MDEQ requirements. 
(Code 1997, § 48-103; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
State Law reference- Hazardous waste management act, MCL 324.11101 et seq. 
Sec. 26-102. - Exterior oil interceptors. 
    Exterior grease/oil interceptors shall be required for all proposed restaurants, food service establishments, gas stations, auto service areas or repair facilities, and on all other businesses as determined by the director of public services or city engineer. This requirement can be waived by the city administrator when a viable alternate is proposed. 
(Code 1997, § 48-104; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-103. - Plan requirements. 
    Sanitary sewer plans shall include size, quantity, and location tables, and show calculations for the sanitary sewer basis of design. 
(Code 1997, § 48-105; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 26-104. - MDEQ permit requirement. 
    The developer's engineer shall complete and submit MDEQ Part 41 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.4101 et seq.) (formerly Act 98) permit applications. 
(Code 1997, § 48-106; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Secs. 26-105-26-121. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMBINED SEWER SYSTEM 

Sec. 26-122. - Plan requirements. 
    In those areas serviced by a combined sewer, the storm sewer and the sanitary sewer will be constructed separate. The separate sewers will be connected to the receiving combined sewer at different locations. Where possible, the storm sewers will be constructed with the outlet elevation as near the surface as allowed by the standards to facilitate sewer separation at some later date. Where required, an internal drop manhole will be constructed according to the city's standard details. 
(Code 1997, § 48-131; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Chapter 28 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan Penal Code, MCL 750.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - "Person" defined. 
    When the term "person" is used in this chapter to designate the party whose property may be the subject of any offense, such term shall be construed to include the United States, the state or any other municipal, public or private corporation which may lawfully own any property within the city, as well as individuals. When the term "person" is used in this chapter to designate a party whose actions violate a provision of this chapter, such term shall include the officers of any corporation, or, in the case of a nonincorporated association, those persons under whose direction or control such act was committed. 
(Code 1975, § 8-2-2; Code 1997, § 54-2) 
Sec. 28-2. - Aiding or abetting violation. 
    Every person who shall willfully conceal, advise, assist, aid or abet any other person in the commission of any of the offenses named in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished in the same manner as the principal offender would have been punished upon conviction. 
(Code 1975, § 8-2-3; Code 1997, § 54-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 767.39. 
Sec. 28-3. - Attempt to commit offense-Punishment. 
    Every person who shall attempt to commit any offense prohibited by this chapter, and in such attempt shall do any act toward the commission of such an offense but shall fail in the perpetration thereof, or shall be prevented or intercepted in executing the offense, upon conviction thereof, shall, in case where no provision is made by ordinance for the punishment of such attempt, be punished in the same manner as for the commission of the offense so attempted. 
(Code 1975, § 8-2-4; Code 1997, § 54-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.92. 
Sec. 28-4. - Concealing knowledge of violation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal knowledge of the commission of any offense or to conceal knowledge of any unlawful act as defined in this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-18; Code 1997, § 54-135) 
Sec. 28-5. - Cruelty to animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, possessor or person having the charge or custody of any animal to cruelly whip, beat, neglect, drive or work the animal when unfit for labor, or to carry or cause to be carried on or upon any vehicle, or otherwise, any living animal having the feet or legs tied together or in any other cruel and inhumane manner to carry or cause to be carried any living animal in or upon any vehicle, or otherwise, without providing suitable racks, carts, crates or cages in which such animal may stand or lie down during transportation and while awaiting slaughter, or to abandon any diseased, maimed, hopelessly sick, infirm or disabled animal in any place within the city, or to willfully or negligently permit and allow any aged, diseased, maimed, hopelessly sick or disabled animal to suffer unnecessary torture or pain. 
(Code 1975, § 8-4-4; Code 1997, § 54-7) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, MCL 750.50. 
Sec. 28-6. - Injuring birds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to kill or wound, or attempt to kill or wound, by use of a firearm, slingshot, bow and arrow or otherwise, any bird, or to take the eggs or young of any bird. 
(Code 1975, § 8-4-3; Code 1997, § 54-8) 
State Law reference- Enforcement of laws for protection of wild birds, wild animals, and fish, MCL 324.1601 et seq.; protection and preservation of fish, game, and birds, MCL 324.41101 et seq. 
Sec. 28-7. - Misdemeanors under state law prohibited. 
    Every act prohibited by state law as a misdemeanor is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-44; Code 1997, § 54-11) 
State Law reference- Michigan penal code, MCL 750.1 et seq. 
Sec. 28-8. - Offenses under state law generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act or fail to perform any requirement which is prohibited or required by state law, insofar as such laws are applicable to municipal government. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-34; Code 1997, § 54-12) 
Secs. 28-9-28-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AFFECTING GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS 

Sec. 28-35. - Aiding prisoners to escape. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to aid or assist, by any means whatever, any prisoner, committed to any jail or place of confinement in the city, in any case, civil or criminal, to escape therefrom, whether such escape be effected or not, or to aid or assist any prisoner in escaping or attempting to escape from the custody of any officer, or an officer's deputy or lawful assistant, who shall have the lawful charge of such prisoner. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-1; Code 1997, § 54-41) 
State Law reference- Facilitating escape of or assisting prisoners, MCL 750.183; aiding escape from officer, MCL 750.184. 
Sec. 28-36. - Assaulting public officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly assault, strike, beat or wound any public officer, or an officer's deputy or lawful assistant, while in the discharge of any official duty. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-2; Code 1997, § 54-42) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.479. 
Sec. 28-37. - Crowds following officer having prisoner in custody. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to gather as a crowd and to follow public safety officers when having persons under control or arrest, or while taking any person under arrest to the municipal building of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-3; Code 1997, § 54-43) 
Sec. 28-38. - Escape from custody. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person convicted of any offense or in lawful custody to escape or attempt to escape from custody. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-4; Code 1997, § 54-44) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.193 et seq. 
Sec. 28-39. - False alarm of fire or need for police or ambulance assistance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally make, turn in or give a false alarm of fire or need for police or ambulance assistance, or to aid or abet in the commission of such act. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-5; Code 1997, § 54-45) 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, MCL 750.240; requesting assistance of ambulance service or advanced mobile emergency care service with intent not to use assistance, MCL 750.411d. 
Sec. 28-40. - False report of crime. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or file with the public safety department of the city any false, misleading or unfounded statement or report concerning the commission or alleged commission of any crime occurring within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-6; Code 1997, § 54-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.411a. 
Sec. 28-41. - False representation as city officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be an officer of the city or to attempt to impersonate any such officer, or to, without authority, perform any official act therein on behalf of an officer. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-7; Code 1997, § 54-47) 
State Law reference- False personation, MCL 750.215 et seq. 
Sec. 28-42. - Resisting or interfering with person with police authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or interfere with any police officer, fire officer or member of the department of public safety, or any person duly empowered with police authority, while in the discharge or apparent discharge of such person's official duties, or in any way interfere with or hinder such person in the discharge of such person's duty, or to willfully disobey any reasonable rule, regulation or order as may be set forth in the discharge of such person's duties. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-8; Code 1997, § 54-48) 
State Law reference- Resisting or obstructing officer in discharge of duty, MCL 750.479. 
Sec. 28-43. - Resisting or interfering with city officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere willfully with, resist, delay, obstruct, molest or threaten to molest any officer of the city in the exercise of such officer's official duties. The term "officer," as used in this section, shall include any employee of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-10; Code 1997, § 54-50) 
State Law reference- Resisting or obstructing officer in discharge of duty, MCL 750.479. 
Sec. 28-44. - Furnishing weapons, drugs or other articles to prisoners. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish or attempt to furnish or take into jail or to deliver or attempt to deliver to any prisoner therein confined, or, in the custody of any officer, any weapon, tool, alcoholic liquors, controlled substances or other articles without the consent of the officer in charge. 
(Code 1975, § 8-6-11; Code 1997, § 54-51) 
State Law reference- Alcoholic liquor, controlled substances, and weapons in jails, MCL 801.261 et seq. 
Sec. 28-45. - Disturbing grade stakes, property line markers or similar markers. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove, break, disturb or in any manner injure any grade stake, stone or other mark or monument set by or under the authority of the city engineer to designate grades, corners, property lines or benchmarks, or in any manner erase or deface any letters or figures thereon. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-53; Code 1997, § 54-52) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.383. 
Sec. 28-46. - Obedience to public safety officers; violation as misdemeanor. 
    A person shall not refuse to comply with a lawful order or direction of a public safety officer when that officer, for public interest and safety, is guiding, directing, controlling or regulating traffic in this city. 
(Code 1997, § 54-53; Ord. No. 746, § 1, 5-15-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.479a. 
Secs. 28-47-28-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS 

Sec. 28-66. - Window peeping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to look, peer, peep into or be found loitering around or within view of any window not on such person's own property with the intent of watching or looking through the window, or to enter upon any private property with the intent to commit such act in such a way as to interfere with the occupant's reasonable expectation of privacy. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-58; Code 1997, § 54-10) 
State Law reference- Such person deemed a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(c). 
Sec. 28-67. - Harassment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, with the intent to harass, annoy or alarm another person, to: 
(1)  Follow a person in or about a public place; or 
(2)  Engage in a course of conduct or repeatedly commit acts that alarm or seriously annoy another person and that serve no legitimate purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 8-5-13; Code 1997, § 54-173) 
Sec. 28-68. - Stalking. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Course of conduct means a pattern of conduct composed of a series of two or more separate noncontinuous acts, evidencing a continuity of purpose. 
    Emotional distress means significant mental suffering or distress that may, but does not necessarily require, medical or other professional treatment or counseling. 
    Harassment means conduct directed toward a victim that includes, but is not limited to, repeated or continuing unconsented contact, that would cause a reasonable individual to suffer emotional distress and that actually causes the victim to suffer emotional distress. The term "harassment" does not include constitutionally protected activity or conduct that serves a legitimate purpose. 
    Stalking means a willful course of conduct involving repeated or continuing harassment of another individual that would cause a reasonable person to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, threatened, harassed or molested, and that actually causes the victim to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, threatened, harassed or molested. 
    Unconsented contact means any contact with another individual that is initiated or continued without that individual's consent, or in disregard of that individual's expressed desire that the contact be avoided or discontinued. The term "unconsented contact" includes, but is not limited to, any of the following: 
(1)  Following or appearing within the sight of that individual. 
(2)  Approaching or confronting that individual in a public place or on private property. 
(3)  Appearing at the workplace or residence of that individual. 
(4)  Entering onto or remaining on property owned, leased or occupied by that individual. 
(5)  Contacting that individual by telephone. 
(6)  Sending mail or electronic communications to that individual. 
(7)  Placing an object on, or delivering an object to, property owned, leased or occupied by that individual. 
    Victim means an individual who is the target of a willful course of conduct involving repeated or continuing harassment. 
(b)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in stalking. 
(c)  Probation and orders of court for persons convicted of stalking. The court may place an individual convicted of violating subsection (b) of this section on probation for a term of not more than two years. If a term of probation is ordered, the court may, in addition to any other lawful condition of probation, order the defendant to do any of the following: 
(1)  Refrain from stalking any individual during the term of probation. 
(2)  Refrain from having contact with the victim of the offense. 
(3)  Be evaluated to determine the need for psychiatric, psychological or social counseling, and if determined appropriate by the court, to receive psychiatric, psychological or social counseling at the person's own expense. 
(d)  Presumption. In a prosecution for a violation of this section, evidence that the defendant continued to engage in a course of conduct involving repeated unconsented contact with the victim after having been requested by the victim to discontinue the same or a different form of unconsented contact with the victim shall give rise to a rebuttable presumption that the continuation of the course of conduct caused the victim to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, threatened, harassed or molested. 
(e)  Penalty. A criminal penalty provided for under this section may be imposed in addition to any penalty that may be imposed for any other criminal offense arising from the same conduct or for any contempt of court arising from the same conduct. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-61; Code 1997, § 54-81) 
Sec. 28-69. - Malicious acts involving communication devices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any communications device or service, including but not limited to telephone, internet and wireless providers, with intent to terrorize, frighten, intimidate, threaten, harass, molest or annoy any other person or to disturb the peace and quiet of any other person. Malicious acts include, but are not limited to any of the following: 
(1)  Threatening physical harm or damage to any person or property in the course of a communication. 
(2)  Falsely and deliberately reporting by a telecommunication device that any person has been injured, has suddenly taken ill, has suffered death, or has been a victim of a crime or of an accident. 
(3)  Deliberately refusing or failing to disengage a connection between communication devices, thereby interfering with any communications service. 
(4)  Using any vulgar, indecent, obscene or offensive language or suggesting any lewd or lascivious act in the course of a communication. 
(5)  Repeatedly initiating a communication and, without speaking, deliberately breaking the communication connection as or after the communication is received. 
(6)  Deliberately using a communication device in a repetitive manner which causes interruption in communication transmission or prevents the person from utilizing his communication service. 
(7)  Other acts determined by the court to violate subsection (a) of this section. 
(b)  An offense is committed under this section if the communication either originates or terminates or both originates and terminates in this city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-36; Code 1997, § 54-82; Ord. No. 696, § 1, 3-4-1996) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.540e. 
Sec. 28-70. - Cruelty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cruelly or inhumanely whip, injure, beat or mistreat their wife or husband, child, stepchild or other child under such person's care. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-19; Code 1997, § 54-84) 
State Law reference- Assaults, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Sec. 28-71. - Battery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit battery. A person commits battery if the person intentionally or knowingly, without legal justification and by any means, causes bodily harm to an individual or makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-11; Code 1997, § 54-85) 
State Law reference- Assaults, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Sec. 28-72. - Assault. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to beat, strike, wound or inflict violence upon another person, or to threaten to do or attempt to do such acts, except in defense of their person or property, and then only to the extent necessary to provide such defense. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-7; Code 1997, § 54-86) 
State Law reference- Assaults, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Sec. 28-73. - Domestic assault and/or battery. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to assault or assault and batter his spouse or former spouse, an individual with whom he has had a child in common or a resident or former resident of his household. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to prohibit a parent or guardian, or other person permitted by law or authorized by the parent or guardian, from taking steps to reasonably discipline a child, including the use of reasonable force. 
(c)  A judge or other magistrate shall not refuse to issue an arrest warrant or dismiss a complaint under this section on the grounds that the complaint is signed upon information and belief by an individual other than the victim of the alleged act or acts of domestic assault and/or battery. 
(d)  A person arrested, with or without a warrant, and charged with a violation of this section shall not be released on an interim bond or on his own recognizance, but shall be held until he can be brought before a magistrate for arraignment. If a magistrate is not available or immediate trial cannot be held within 24 hours, the person shall be held for 20 hours, after which the person may be released on an interim bond or released on his own recognizance. 
(e)  Upon a plea of guilty or a conviction of a person for violating this section, the court may consider the options of deferral of proceedings and probation, as and to the extent permitted by MCL 769.4a, and pursuant to the provisions of said section. 
(Code 1997, § 54-87; Ord. No. 716, § 1, 5-19-1997) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Secs. 28-74-28-104. - Reserved.

Sec. 28-124. - Public property damaging or tampering. 
    No person shall under any circumstances damage, destroy, deface or in any manner mar or tamper with any publicly owned building, school building, public structure, fence, utility installation, fire hydrant, tree equipment, mechanical equipment, or any other real or personal public property.

Sec. 28-125. - Removing public property.

Sec. 28-126. - Damaging or destroying property-Personal.

Sec. 28-129. - Posting notices or placards.

State Law reference- Trespassing generally, MCL 750.546 et seq. 

Sec. 28-157. - Trespass on property after being notified to leave premises. 
    Any person being upon the lands or premises of the city, church, school, library or other public or private institution, who, being notified to depart therefrom orally or by a sign posted on the premises by the owner, occupant, agent or servant of the owner or occupant, or any person having authority with respect to the presence of others upon such premises, neglects or refuses to depart therefrom, shall be deemed guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter.

Sec. 28-158. - Trespass on property where entry prohibited. 
    Any person who shall willfully and without lawful authority enter upon the lands or premises of the city or any church, school, library or other public or private institution after having been forbidden so to do, orally or by a sign posted on the premises by the owner, occupant, or agent or servant of the owner or occupant, or any person having authority with respect to the presence of others upon such premises, shall be deemed guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-55; Code 1997, § 54-116) 
Sec. 28-159. - Prowling about on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful to prowl about on the private premises of any other person in the nighttime without authority or the permission of the owner of such premises. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-51; Code 1997, § 54-118)

DIVISION 4. - THEFT OR FRAUD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Larceny generally, MCL 750.356 et seq. 

Sec. 28-187. - Swindling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to, by color, aid of any trick or sleight of hand performance, or by fraud or by fraudulent scheme, cards, dice or device, win for such person or for another any money or property, or a representative of either. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-54; Code 1997, § 54-117) 
State Law reference- Gross frauds and cheats at common law, MCL 750.280. 
Sec. 28-188. - Larceny. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of larceny by stealing the property of another having a value of less than $200.00. The term "property," as used in this section, includes: 
(1)  Money, goods or chattals. 
(2)  A banknote, bank bill, bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order or certificate. 
(3)  A book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due, to become due or to be delivered. 
(4)  A deed or writing containing a conveyance of land or other valuable contract in force. 
(5)  A receipt, release or defeasance. 
(6)  A writ, process or public record. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-47; Code 1997, § 54-122; Ord. No. 750, § 1, 6-19-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.356. 
Sec. 28-189. - Receiving or concealing stolen property. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to buy, receive, possess, conceal or aid in the concealment of stolen, embezzled or converted money, goods, or property having a value of less than $200.00 knowing the money, goods or property is stolen, embezzled or converted. 
(b)  Presumption on dealer's failure to make reasonable inquiry. A person who is a dealer in or collector of merchandise or personal property, or the agent, employee, or representative of a dealer or collector of merchandise or personal property who fails to reasonably inquire whether the person selling or delivering the stolen, embezzled or converted property to the dealer or collector has a legal right to do so or who buys or receives stolen, embezzled or converted property that has a registration, serial number or other identifying number altered or obliterated on an external surface of the property, is presumed to have bought or received the property to knowing the property is stolen, embezzled or converted. This presumption is rebuttable. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-48; Code 1997, § 54-123; Ord. No. 749, § 1, 6-19-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.535. 
Sec. 28-190. - Fraud generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain money or other valuable things, or to aid or abet such act, or in any manner to be concerned therein. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-33; Code 1997, § 54-128) 
State Law reference- Gross fraud and cheats, MCL 750.280. 
Sec. 28-191. - Obtaining food or merchandise under false pretenses; failure to pay for food or merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain any food, drink, goods, wares or merchandise under false pretenses, or to enter any public place and call for refreshments or other articles and receive and refuse to pay for such articles, or depart without paying for such articles or satisfying the person from whom the food, goods, wares or merchandise were received. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-22; Code 1997, § 54-129) 
State Law reference- Defrauding hotel, motel, inn, restaurant, cafe, MCL 750.292. 
Sec. 28-192. - Checks without sufficient funds-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository with intent to defraud and knowing at the time of the making, drawing, uttering or delivering that the maker or drawer does not have sufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository to pay the check, draft, or order in full upon its presentation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository with intent to defraud if the person does not have sufficient funds for the payment of the check, draft, or order when presentation for payment is made to the drawee. This subsection does not apply if the lack of funds is due to garnishment, attachment, levy, or other lawful cause and that fact was not known to the person when the person made, drew, uttered, or delivered the check, draft, or order. 
(c)  If the amount of the check, draft, or order is less than $100.00, a person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor or punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days, a fine of not more than $500.00, or both imprisonment and fine. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-13; Code 1997, § 54-130; Ord. No. 751, § 1, 6-19-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.131. 
Sec. 28-193. - Same-Evidence of intent to defraud. 
    As against the maker or drawer thereof, the making, drawing, uttering or delivering of a check, draft or order, payment of which is refused by the drawee, when presented in the usual course of business, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds in, or credit with, such bank or other depository; provided such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee thereof the amount due thereon, together with all costs and protest fees, within five days after receiving notice that such check, draft or order has not been paid by the drawee. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-14; Code 1997, § 54-131) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.132. 
Sec. 28-194. - Same-Notice of protest. 
    Where a check, draft or order is protested on the grounds of insufficiency of funds or credit, the notice of protest thereof shall be admissible as proof of presentation, nonpayment and protest, and shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds or credit with such bank or other depository. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-15; Code 1997, § 54-132) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.133. 
Sec. 28-195. - Same-"Credit" defined. 
    The term "credit," as used in sections 28-192 through 28-194, shall be construed to mean any arrangement or understanding with the bank or depository for the payment of such check, draft or order in full upon presentation thereof for payment. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-16; Code 1997, § 54-133) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.134. 
Sec. 28-196. - Possession or use of financial transaction device belonging to other person. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in such person's possession or to use or attempt to use any financial transaction device belonging to any other person without such person's permission. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-17; Code 1997, § 54-134) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.157n. 
Sec. 28-197. - Breaking and entering coin box. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously and willfully, by and with the aid and use of any key, instrument, device or explosive, blow or attempt to blow, or force or attempt to force an entrance into any coin box, depository box, newspaper coin box or other receptacle established and maintained for the convenience of the public, or for any person to extract or obtain or attempt to extract or obtain therefrom any such money or thing of value so deposited or contained therein. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-12; Code 1997, § 54-136) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.113. 
Sec. 28-198. - Fraudulently avoiding payment of admission fees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person fraudulently to enter, without payment of the proper admission fee, any theater, ballroom, lecture, concert or other place where admission fees are charged; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to prohibit or restrict the free admission of police officers engaged in the performance of police duties to any place of public entertainment or amusement. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3-1; Code 1997, § 54-137) 
Secs. 28-199-28-219. - Reserved.

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Gambling generally, MCL 750.301 et seq. 

Sec. 28-251. - Engaging in gambling; frequenting gambling establishment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deal in, play or engage in gaming such as faro, roulette, dice, cards or other devices or games of chance, hazard or skill, either as bookmaker, dealer, keeper, player or otherwise, for the purpose of gambling for money or other valuable things, or to attend or be found frequenting any place where gambling is permitted or allowed or is taking place. 
(Code 1975, § 8-5-3; Code 1997, § 54-163) 
State Law reference- Frequenting or attending gaming places, MCL 750.309. 
Sec. 28-252. - Keeping gaming room or gaming table. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain for hire, gain or reward a gaming room or gaming table, or any game of skill or chance, or partly of skill and partly of chance, used for gaming, or to knowingly suffer a gaming room or gaming table or any such game to be kept, maintained or played on any premises within the city occupied or controlled by such person, or for any person to aid, assist or abet in the keeping or maintaining of any such gaming room, gaming table or game within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-5-4; Code 1997, § 54-164) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.303.

(Code 1975, § 8-5-5; Code 1997, § 54-165) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.302. 
Sec. 28-254. - Conducting or promoting lottery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to promote, establish, conduct, operate or manage, superintend, or to aid or to assist in making, establishing, promoting, conducting, operating, managing or superintending, any lottery, gift enterprise, policy, scheme or drawing in the nature of a lottery in the city, or to knowingly advertise or to make public in any manner any lottery, gift enterprise, policy or scheme in the nature of a lottery, whether the lottery is being or is to be conducted, held or drawn within or without the city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-5-6; Code 1997, § 54-166) 
State Law reference- Pool tickets, MCL 750.306. 
Sec. 28-255. - Keeping betting room; buying or selling pools. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, or such person's agent or employee, to directly or indirectly keep, maintain, operate or occupy any building or room, or any part thereof, or any place with apparatus, books or any device for registering bets, or buying or selling pools upon the result of a trial or contest of skill, speed or endurance, or upon the result of a game, competition, political competition, appointment or election, or any purported event of like character, or to register bets, or buy or sell pools, or to be concerned in buying or selling pools, or to knowingly permit any grounds or premises owned, occupied or controlled by him to be used for any of the purposes mentioned in this section. 
(Code 1975, § 8-5-7; Code 1997, § 54-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.304. 
Sec. 28-256. - Possession of policy tickets or other gambling materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be in possession of any policy or pool tickets, slips or checks, memoranda of any combination, or other bet, manifold or other policy, or pool books or sheets, or any of such articles, or any other implements, apparatus or materials of any other form of gaming. 
(Code 1975, § 8-5-8; Code 1997, § 54-168)
