    Before any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place shall be paved, resurfaced, repaved, widened or otherwise improved, notice thereof shall be furnished to all public service corporations and similar persons concerned. Prior to any excavation or treatment of existing street or alley surfaces, such persons shall lay therein all wires, pipes, poles, cables, conduits and the like which may be deemed necessary or contemplated by the utility during the life of the improvement. On the recommendation of the city administrator, the council may, by resolution, set a reasonable time limit prior to which all work on such wires, pipes, poles, cables, conduits and the like in the street, alley, sidewalk or other public places to be improved must be completed. Any person who, without the written consent of the director of public services, continues to do such work after the expiration of the time set shall be subject to the penalties provided in this Code. Failure of the city to give or receive notice to or from specific persons shall not affect the other provisions of this article or the penalties hereby imposed. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6-9; Code 1997, § 74-83) 
Sec. 38-69. - Barriers and warning lights; temporary sidewalks and other structures. 
(a)  Any person making or causing to be made an excavation or opening in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place or within five feet of the line of any street or public place shall, between sunset and sunrise on every night that such excavation or opening remains open or danger exists therefrom, keep such excavation or opening fenced or barricaded and properly lighted so as to warn all persons of such excavation or opening and all obstructions. No unauthorized person shall remove or interfere in any way with any such lantern, kerosene bomb or other danger signal or any such barriers. 
(b)  When it is necessary to block or close a sidewalk to pedestrian traffic, safe temporary walks with guardrails or fences shall be provided as requested by the director of public services or the director of public safety. 
(c)  Bridges across a trench shall be built of sound material with substantial guardrails and of sufficient width and strength to accommodate the pedestrian traffic without danger. When it is necessary to provide bridges for vehicular traffic across openings too large to permit the use of steel plates, such bridges shall be substantially constructed of sufficient width and strength to permit the safe passage of traffic. Temporary structures, fences or bridges shall be maintained in a safe passable condition at all times. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6-10; Code 1997, § 74-84) 
Sec. 38-70. - Work to conform to city specifications. 
    All work under a permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be under the jurisdiction of the director of public services and shall be accomplished in conformity with the specifications as approved by resolution of the city council and on file with the city clerk, which specifications may be amended from time to time by the city council, with copies of the amended specifications being forwarded to the respective public utility companies. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6-11; Code 1997, § 74-85) 
Sec. 38-71. - Failure to comply with permit conditions. 
    If any person to whom a permit under this article has been granted shall fail to comply with the terms thereof, such permit shall become null and void, and any and all expenses, including administrative costs, which may be incurred by the city in making the necessary restoration, repair or replacement of any excavation made on, in or under the surface or pavement of any street, alley, sidewalk, driveway approach or unimproved public property shall be borne by the permittee. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6-12; Code 1997, § 74-86) 
Sec. 38-72. - Enforcement of article. 
    All public safety officers shall be vigilant in the enforcement of the provisions of this article and shall report through proper channels any violation thereof to the director of public services on observing or being informed of the opening of or excavation in any street, and shall require the person making such opening or excavation to exhibit the permit therefor. If no permit has been issued, or if the exhibition thereof is refused, the officer shall, without delay, enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6-13; Code 1997, § 74-87) 
Secs. 38-73-38-102. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MATERIALS ON STREETS 

Sec. 38-103. - Unlawful deposits of materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, dump or wash sand, gravel, asphalt, cement or other similar materials from tools, equipment or transporting trucks; or to allow such materials or debris, grass cuttings, dirt, sod or similar or like substances deposited on a paved or graveled surface to flow or be poured into a street, alley, gutter, drainage ditch, sewer or catchbasin at any time. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-1; Code 1997, § 74-111) 
Sec. 38-104. - Permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit sand, gravel, equipment, dumpsters or containers upon any street or alley without first having acquired a permit for such activity from the department of public services. Contractors working under contract with the city are exempt from acquiring a permit for work associated with such contract. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-2; Code 1997, § 74-112) 
Sec. 38-105. - Same-Fee; deposit. 
    Where an application for a permit to deposit materials or equipment upon a street or alley indicates that such materials or equipment will be removed the same day as deposited and will not obstruct travel upon the roadways, a permit may be issued by the department of public services without a permit fee, but if it shall appear from such application that such equipment or materials will remain on the street or alley for a longer period, then a permit fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be required, together with a deposit of $200.00, which shall be held as security for the prompt and proper removal of all materials or equipment deposited under any permit issued. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-3; Code 1997, § 74-113) 
Sec. 38-106. - Deductions from deposit. 
    The director of public services or the director's designated representative shall deduct from any security deposit any costs or expenses incurred by the city in removing any equipment or materials deposited under the permit issued under this article or to cover the costs of restoring any street or alley to its original condition. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-4; Code 1997, § 74-114) 
Sec. 38-107. - Deposit of materials. 
    Any person to whom a permit under this article has been issued shall deposit the materials or place the equipment in the space designated in such permit and in no other place upon the streets or alleys. Materials deposited upon streets surfaced by the chip and seal process shall be deposited only upon plywood or other protective materials so that the deposited material does not come into contact with the surface of the roadway. The permit holder shall notify the department of public services in advance of depositing materials or equipment under the provisions of any permit issued. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-5; Code 1997, § 74-115) 
Sec. 38-108. - Barriers and safeguards. 
    It shall be the duty of any person depositing materials or equipment on streets or alleys to provide lighted barriers or lighted sawhorses and safeguards to warn the public against the obstruction created by depositing such materials or equipment. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-6; Code 1997, § 74-116) 
Sec. 38-109. - Refund of deposit. 
    The director of public services or his designated representative, upon removal of the materials or equipment from the street or alley, shall refund to the depositor any sums remaining on hand in the deposit fund provided for in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-7; Code 1997, § 74-117) 
Sec. 38-110. - Protection of sidewalk and curb. 
    Any contractor or permit holder under this article shall provide sufficient cover or protection for any sidewalk or curb over which materials are to be hauled so as to prevent damage to such sidewalks or curbs. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7-8; Code 1997, § 74-118) 
Secs. 38-111-38-133. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-134. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parades and processions means and includes parades, processions, fun runs, group walks, marathon walks or races, bike-a-thons, and similar events as interpreted by the city administrator. 
(Code 1975, § 8-17-1; Code 1997, § 74-141; Ord. No. 805, § 74-141, 9-19-2005) 
Secs. 38-135-38-151. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 38-152. - Required. 
    All parades and processions conducted within the city shall require a permit. Application for such a permit shall be made in writing and submitted to the city clerk no less than 90 days prior to the date such event is scheduled to occur. 
(Code 1975, § 8-17-2; Code 1997, § 74-161; Ord. No. 805, § 74-161, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 38-153. - Information required. 
    The application for a parade or procession permit shall contain such information as may be required by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 8-17-3; Code 1997, § 74-162; Ord. No. 805, § 74-162, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 38-154. - Standards for approval. 
(a)  The city clerk shall submit the application for a parade or procession permit to the department of public safety for review and comment concerning the following: 
(1)  Traffic and pedestrian safety measures that may be required. 
(2)  The necessity of marshals to assist in directing or controlling the participants in the event, and the estimated number of participants. 
(3)  The estimated additional manpower of the public safety department that will be required to handle the proposed event and the hours of overtime, if any, that may be required. 
(4)  Whether or not such proposed event will apparently conflict with other events in the city such as regular or special church services, business promotions or other events. 
(b)  Upon receiving the report from the department of public safety, as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the city administrator shall estimate the costs that will be incurred by the city if the activity takes place. If the application is an organization's first request for a permit under this article, then the city administrator shall refer the application for a permit, the report of the department of public safety, and the administrator's recommendations to the city council for consideration. However, if the council has previously approved an organization's request for a permit of a substantially similar event, then subsequent renewals of the permit may be approved by the city administrator subject to the standards for approval (report from department of public safety and cost estimate still required) and conditions for approval contained in this article. Any denial of renewal requests may be submitted to city council. 
(Code 1975, § 8-17-4; Code 1997, § 74-163; Ord. No. 805, § 74-163, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 38-155. - Grant or denial by council; conditions for approval. 
    The city council shall consider an application for a permit under the provisions of this article and may deny such request or may approve such request subject to conditions which may include any of the following: 
(1)  The applicant agrees to reimburse the city part or all of the costs incurred by the city because of such event. A performance deposit may be required to guarantee such payment to the city. 
(2)  Require the applicant to furnish the number of marshals that have been indicated as necessary by the department of public safety. The applicant may be required to provide readily identifiable clothing, uniform jackets or arm patches for the marshals and agree that such marshals shall be used to assist in traffic control or crowd control under the direction of the department of public safety. 
(3)  Require the applicant to agree to remove any debris, which may be associated with or generated by the event, or to agree to reimburse the city for cleanup costs incurred by the city. 
(4)  Require the applicant obtain the prior approval of any businesses, schools, churches or other entities that may be affected by the event. 
(5)  Require the applicant to obtain permission for such event from the county road commission if the use of Mack Avenue is requested. 
(6)  Require the applicant to obtain liability insurance protecting the city from potential risks associated with the event, including the amount of such coverage. 
(7)  Require the applicant to meet any other condition that is deemed in the best interests of the city and its residents. 
(Code 1975, § 8-17-5; Code 1997, § 74-164; Ord. No. 805, § 74-164, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 38-156. - Automatic revocation. 
    Should the permit requested under this article be issued conditioned upon the applicant fulfilling certain requirements prior to the event and should the applicant fail or neglect fulfilling any such condition, then the approval for such event as obtained from the city council or city administrator shall be automatically rescinded. 
(Code 1975, § 8-17-6; Code 1997, § 74-165; Ord. No. 805, § 74-165, 9-19-2005) 
Secs. 38-157-38-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SNOW REMOVAL 

Sec. 38-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership or corporation, but shall not include the state or a political subdivision of the state, an employee of the state or an employee of a political subdivision of the state operating within the scope of such employee's duties for the state or political subdivision thereof. The term "corporation" shall include the officers thereof. 
    Safe vision means an unobstructed line of sight enabling a driver of a motor vehicle to travel upon, enter or exit a roadway or alley, including a dedicated right-of-way open for vehicular travel, in a safe manner. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-1; Code 1997, § 74-186) 
Sec. 38-182. - Obstructing safe vision prohibited. 
    No person shall remove or deposit, or cause to be removed or deposited, snow, ice or slush onto or across a street right-of-way, roadway or alley in any manner that obstructs the safe vision of the driver of a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-2; Code 1997, § 74-187) 
Sec. 38-183. - Deposits on roadway prohibited. 
    No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited snow, ice or slush on any roadway or alley. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-3; Code 1997, § 74-188) 
Sec. 38-184. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, for money or other valuable thing, to use a motor vehicle to remove, plow or shovel snow or slush from any land or premises within the city without first obtaining and maintaining a snow removal license from the city. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-4; Code 1997, § 74-189) 
Sec. 38-185. - Application for license. 
    Application for a snow removal license shall be made upon a form provided by the city clerk. The applicant shall provide the following information to the city clerk: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the individual, firm, partnership or corporation requesting such license. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner or tenant and location of the property where such snow removal operations will be or are intended to be conducted. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-5; Code 1997, § 74-190) 
Sec. 38-186. - Fee and term of license. 
    The applicant for a snow removal license shall pay a license fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time to the city, and upon approval of such license and receipt of the fee, the city clerk shall issue the applicant a snow removal license, which license shall expire July 1 of each year. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-6; Code 1997, § 74-191) 
Sec. 38-187. - List of customers. 
    Any licensee holding a snow removal license shall keep the city clerk advised, in writing, of the name and address of any new or additional customers and locations where snow removal activities will be or are intended to be conducted. It shall be a violation of this Code for any person having a snow removal license to use a motor vehicle to remove, plow or shovel snow within the city at a location or premise not listed with the city clerk as a customer or location of such licensee. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7-7; Code 1997, § 74-192) 
Secs. 38-188, 38-189. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SNOW EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 38-190. - Parking prohibited. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no person shall park a motor vehicle on any street or alley during a declared snow emergency. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-191. - Method of declaration; procedure. 
(a)  In the interest of the public health, safety and welfare, the city administrator or designated representative may declare a snow emergency whenever, in his or her judgment, ice or snow has accumulated or is significantly likely to accumulate to such an extent as to impede safe travel upon the streets of the city. 
(b)  Method of declaration. 
(1)  Mandatory. A snow emergency shall exist when the city administrator declares an emergency to be publicly announced by broadcast from one or more radio or television stations within normal operating range covering the city. 
(2)  Discretionary. When practical, such declaration shall also be made over the appropriate cable television channel, on the city hall telephone message machine, and the city website. 
(3)  The city administrator shall make a record of each time and date and methods of such declaration. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-192. - Duration of no parking ban. 
(a)  The parking prohibition shall begin one hour after a snow emergency has been declared. The prohibition shall end on any individual street when both of the following conditions have been satisfied: 
(1)  The snow, ice or sleet has stopped. 
(2)  The city has completed snow plowing on that street from curb to curb for the entire block. 
(b)  The parking prohibition shall, in general, expire 48 hours after the weather conditions creating the emergency have stopped, unless the state of emergency is extended. Such an extension shall require that the procedures outlined in section 38-191 be repeated. 
(c)  Despite expiration of the no parking ban of a declared snow emergency, a parked vehicle surrounded or partially surrounded by plowed snow, shall constitute a presumption that the vehicle was parked in violation of the no parking ban. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-193. - Abandoning disabled vehicles. 
    Whenever a vehicle becomes disabled for any reason on any street during a parking prohibition for snow emergency, the owner or person operating the vehicle shall take immediate action to have the vehicle towed or pushed off the street. No person shall abandon or leave a vehicle on the street except for the purpose of securing immediate assistance and in such cases the person securing assistance shall leave the vehicle only for the time actually necessary to make contact for assistance and shall return to the vehicle thereafter without delay. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-194. - Impounding of vehicles. 
    The public safety department is hereby authorized to remove a vehicle which is parked on any street during a declared snow emergency and to transport the vehicle to an impound facility designated by the city. Prior to impounding a vehicle, the city shall take reasonable steps to attempt to provide the owner of the vehicle with actual notice pursuant to a written policy approved by the city council, as amended by resolution. Towing and impound fees shall be charged to the owner of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-195. - Presumption of ownership: failure to receive notice. 
    Proof that the particular vehicle described in a complaint was parked in violation of this article, together with proof that the respondent named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute a presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle in violation of this chapter. If this presumption is rebutted, the owner of the vehicle may be required to produce evidence regarding the person who actually parked the vehicle in violation of this article. The failure of a respondent to receive notice of a snow emergency shall not be a defense. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-196. - Exception for hardship. 
    The director of public safety or his or her designated representative shall have the authority to issue an annual permit for on-street parking during a declared snow emergency upon the applicant's compliance with the requirements of this chapter and proof of hardship. Issuance of a permit is discretionary and shall be based on the same criteria utilized for issuing permits for parking vehicles between 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. The annual permit fee shall be $25.00, as amended by council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-197. - Permit required; application information. 
    A permit is required for each vehicle parked on the street during a designated snow emergency. Permits shall be nontransferable and valid for not more than one year. All permits shall expire on March 31 of each year in any event. Application for a permit shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  Copies of the titles, registrations or lease agreements for all vehicles at the location; 
(2)  Copies of the drivers' licenses of the immediate family members residing at the location at the time of application; and 
(3)  Payment of $25.00 for each permit, as amended by council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-198. - Permit display; authorized parking. 
    In the event the director of public safety or his or her designated representative grants a permit pursuant to this article, such permit shall be in the form of a sticker which the applicant shall affix in the driver's side inside front lower left window of the permitted vehicle. The application shall contain the year, model and license plate number of the vehicle. A vehicle properly bearing such a sticker shall be permitted to park either in front of, or directly across from the permitted residence depending on existing signage. If such a vehicle cannot be so parked for reasons not created by the applicant, then such a vehicle may be parked within 50 feet of the residence. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-199. - Relationship to other laws. 
    Any provision of this article which becomes effective shall, while temporarily in effect, take precedence over other conflicting provisions of law normally in effect, except that it shall not take precedent over provisions of law relating to traffic accidents, emergency travel of authorized emergency vehicles, or emergency traffic directions by a police officer. However, nothing in this article shall be construed to permit parking at any time or place where it is forbidden by any other provision of law. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-200. - Violations. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Park a vehicle on a street during a declared snow emergency without a permit or with a permit improperly displayed; 
(2)  Transfer a permit to a vehicle other than the one for which it was issued; 
(3)  Falsify any information or documentation required by this chapter for issuance of a permit; or 
(4)  Park a permitted vehicle contrary to section 38-198. 
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 38-201. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provisions of this article shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction or misdemeanor as defined by this Code and upon a finding of responsibility shall be subject to a civil fine in accordance with the following schedule: 
1 st violation: Up to $100.00, as amended by council resolution. 2 nd violation: Up to $200.00, as amended by council resolution. 3 rd or subsequent violation: Misdemeanor.  
(Ord. No. 830, 9-14-2009) 
Secs. 38-202-38-225. - Reserved. 
Chapter 40 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Land division act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 

Sec. 40-1. - Regulations applicable to subdivisions. 
    The subdivider is urged to become acquainted with the following state statutes and provisions of this Code prior to actual work on any proposed subdivision: 
(1)  Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.). Copies of this item may be obtained from the auditor general of the state at Lansing. 
(2)  This chapter and chapter 50. Copies of these items may be obtained from the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-1; Code 1997, § 78-1) 
Sec. 40-2. - Discussion of drainage plans with city administrator. 
    Before the subdivider shall confer with the city engineer relative to stormwater drainage plans, the matter shall be discussed with the city administrator, who, in his judgment, may then refer the matter of drainage plans to the city engineer, such reference to be made by written direction. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-2; Code 1997, § 78-2) 
Sec. 40-3. - Submission of deed restrictions and preliminary plat; contents of preliminary plat. 
    At least seven days prior to the scheduled meeting of the planning commission, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission 14 copies of deed restrictions and 14 copies of the preliminary plat. Regular meetings of the planning commission are held on the fourth Tuesday of each month. The preliminary plat shall show: 
(1)  The subdivision name and location. 
(2)  Identity and addresses of all owners, and identity and address of the designer or engineer. 
(3)  Date of submission to the planning commission. 
(4)  North point and graphic scale of the plat. 
(5)  Location of property lines, location of streets, location of existing utilities, location of existing easements and location of proposed easements. 
(6)  Present zoning classification. 
(7)  Names of adjoining properties or subdivisions. 
(8)  Proposed utility system (water mains and sewers), with sizes indicated. 
(9)  Names of new streets or extensions of existing streets. 
(10)  Lot lines, lot dimensions and lot numbers. 
(11)  House numbering system obtained from the city engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-3; Code 1997, § 78-3) 
Sec. 40-4. - Forwarding of deed restrictions and preliminary plat to planning commissioners. 
    Following initial study by the city, a copy of the deed restrictions and the preliminary plat will be forwarded to each planning commissioner prior to the next scheduled meeting. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-4; Code 1997, § 78-4) 
Sec. 40-5. - Action by planning commission on deed restrictions and preliminary plat. 
    After approval by the planning commission of the deed restrictions and the preliminary plat, one copy of each shall be filed in the city's master subdivision file. The remaining copies shall be held by the city administrator for use by the council. The planning commission shall advise the council and the subdivider of its action in connection with the deed restrictions and the preliminary plat. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-5; Code 1997, § 78-5) 
Sec. 40-6. - Review of preliminary plat by utility company. 
    A copy of the approved preliminary plat, appropriately stamped and signed, should be submitted by the subdivider to: 
The Detroit Edison Company 
9980 Gratiot Avenue 
Detroit, Michigan 
Attention: Engineering Department 
Planning Division 
for its recommendation on the number and location of streetlights and light poles, including necessary easements to permit their installation. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-6; Code 1997, § 78-6) 
Sec. 40-7. - Review of preliminary plat by director of public safety. 
    The secretary of the planning commission shall submit two copies of the approved preliminary plat to the director of public safety, who shall: 
(1)  Make recommendations on the street pattern and characteristics of the preliminary plat. 
(2)  Enter thereon recommendations on the location of fire hydrants. 
(3)  Enter the number, location and price (installed) of the necessary street and traffic signs. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-7; Code 1997, § 78-7) 
Sec. 40-8. - Review of water, sewer and street plans. 
(a)  The subdivider shall make the data acquired under sections 40-6 and 40-7 available to the subdivider's engineer, after which the subdivider shall submit detailed plans and design data of water mains, sewers, concrete pavements and sidewalks to the city engineer, together with detailed estimates of the cost of these improvements. 
(b)  The city engineer will forward water and sewer plans to the state department of health, the county water and sewage authority and the City of Detroit for their approval. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-8; Code 1997, § 78-8) 
Sec. 40-9. - Prerequisites for preparation of final plat. 
    After notice of approval of the plans and design data of water mains, sewers, concrete pavements and sidewalks by the city engineer and approval by the state department of health, the county water and sewage authority, and the City of Detroit, the subdivider's designer or engineer may prepare a final plat. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-9; Code 1997, § 78-9) 
Sec. 40-10. - Submission of final plat, fees and improvement bond. 
    The subdivider shall submit the final plat on approved material and ten prints thereof to the council at least three days prior to the next scheduled meeting, together with: 
(1)  A letter from the city engineer approving the design of utilities and confirming the subdivider's estimate of the cost of all improvements, plus a deposit for inspection costs estimated to be two percent of the cost of all improvements, plus a deposit of one-half percent of the cost of all improvements for engineering fees. 
(2)  A fee of $60.00 (land division act, MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(3)  A subdivider's improvement bond in the amount of the total estimated costs of the improvements and inspection fees, together with a guarantee of the materials and construction of such improvements for a period of one year from and after the date of the acceptance of such improvements by the city; provided that the subdivider may substitute a surety bond of the contractor, in favor of the city, guaranteeing the improvement against defects in workmanship and materials for a period of one year from and after the date of acceptance of the improvement by the city, which surety bond shall be in the principal sum of ten percent of the contract cost of the improvement for improvements installed prior to January 1, 1963, and in the principal sum of 15 percent of the contract cost of the improvements installed thereafter. No such improvement shall be accepted by the city unless and until such bond is filed and accepted. The subdivider shall be responsible for the installation of the following improvements: 
a.  Adequate water mains, including necessary fire hydrants. 
b.  Adequate sewers and drainage facilities, including positive rear yard drainage. 
c.  Concrete pavement and concrete sidewalks. 
d.  Necessary street and traffic signs. 
e.  The planting of trees between the sidewalk and the curb, which trees shall be of a minimum size of one inch to 11/2 inches in diameter and six feet to eight feet in height and shall be so spaced so that there shall be a distance of not less than 40 feet and not more than 80 feet between existing trees or trees to be so planted. The provisions of article III of chapter 46 shall be complied with in connection with the planting of any such trees. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-10; Code 1997, § 78-10) 
Sec. 40-11. - Enforcement of compliance. 
    The subdivider's improvement bond (performance bond) will not be released, nor will building permits be issued, until all of the regulations of this article have been complied with. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-11; Code 1997, § 78-11) 
Sec. 40-12. - Improvements to be installed and accepted before issuance of building permits. 
    Before building permits are issued in any subdivision, the improvements, consisting of the necessary sewers, water mains and paving, as approved by the city engineer, shall have been installed and accepted by the city. The installation of sidewalks shall be under the direction of the city engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-12; Code 1997, § 78-12) 
Sec. 40-13. - Conditions for approval of subdivision prior to installation of improvements. 
    The council may, in its discretion, approve any subdivision plat without such improvements being first installed if the owners of the property platted shall give to the city a bond conditioned upon the owners either within 12 months after such approval installing such improvements at their own expense, or petitioning the proper public authorities for such improvements on the basis of special assessment of all the cost thereof against the property benefited within such time as will reasonably permit such installation within 12 months after such approval. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-13; Code 1997, § 78-13) 
Sec. 40-14. - Street widths. 
    All streets, which shall be platted or dedicated to the public's use within the limits of the city shall be of a width to be established by the council. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-14; Code 1997, § 78-14) 
Sec. 40-15. - Sewer system. 
    No plat of land shall be approved by the council until a sewer system satisfactory to the city engineer or council shall have been installed at the expense of the owners of the property platted; provided that the council may, in its discretion, approve any such plat without such improvements being first installed if the owners of the property platted shall give to the city a bond conditioned upon the owners either within 12 months after such approval installing such improvements at their own expense, or petitioning the proper public authorities for such improvements on the basis of special assessment of all the cost thereof against the property benefited within such time as will reasonably permit such installation within 12 months after such approval. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-15; Code 1997, § 78-15) 
Sec. 40-16. - Street pavement and drainage. 
    No plat of land shall be approved by the council until pavement on streets on which lots front and a system of surface drains on all streets satisfactory to the city engineer or council shall have been installed at the expense of the owners of the property platted; provided that the council may, in its discretion, approve any such plat without such improvements being first installed if the owners of the property platted shall give to the city a bond conditioned upon the owners either installing such improvements at their own expense, or petitioning the proper public authorities for such improvements on a basis of special assessment of all the cost thereof against the property benefited within such time as will reasonably permit such installation within 12 months after such approval. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-16; Code 1997, § 78-16) 
Sec. 40-17. - Sidewalks. 
    No plat of land shall be approved by the council until sidewalks on both sides of each street not less than five feet wide (except that sidewalks along Mack Avenue frontage shall be not be less than six feet wide), satisfactory to the city engineer or council, shall have been installed at the expense of the owners of the property platted; provided that the council may, in its discretion, approve any such plat without such improvements being first installed if the owners of the property platted shall give to the city a bond conditioned upon the owners within 12 months after such approval installing such improvements at their own expense. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-17; Code 1997, § 78-17) 
Sec. 40-18. - Water mains and fire hydrants. 
    No plat of land shall be approved by the city council until the following improvements shall have been installed at the expense of the owner of the property and in a manner satisfactory to the city council: 
(1)  Water mains. Water mains shall be constructed and laid in all streets, and connections shall be established with the sources of supply of the city. 
(2)  Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants of a kind and size to be approved by the city engineer or by the division of public works shall be installed along all streets not more than 500 feet apart. The location of the hydrants shall be approved by the department of public safety. 
The council may, in its discretion, approve any such plat without such improvements being first installed if the owners of the property platted shall give to the city a bond conditioned upon the owners either, within 12 months after such approval, installing such improvements at their own expense, or petitioning the proper public authorities for such improvements on a basis of special assessment of all the cost thereof against the property benefited within such time as will reasonably permit such installation within 12 months after such approval. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-18; Code 1997, § 78-18) 
Sec. 40-19. - Landscaping of parkways and culs-de-sac. 
    It shall be the duty of the subdivider of property which provides for culs-de-sac or parkways, which may hereafter be presented for approval, to landscape all culs-de-sac and parkways, providing that the provisions of this section shall not be deemed to apply to the space between the property line and the street line of residential lots, where such lots abut upon any cul-de-sac or parkway. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-19; Code 1997, § 78-19) 
Sec. 40-20. - Removal of debris. 
    It shall be the duty of the subdivider to provide for the removal of all dead trees, logs and debris from the premises and to provide for the removal of all trees from the street right-of-way and the sidewalk right-of-way. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-20; Code 1997, § 78-20) 
Sec. 40-21. - Street signs and traffic signs. 
    The subdivider of any plat shall be required to install all street signs and traffic signs and, in order to guarantee the installation thereof, shall be required to deposit with the clerk a sum of money sufficient to cover the costs of such installations. The street and traffic signs shall be of such design and structural requirements as shall be in conformity with the standards approved and used by the city. The subdivider may authorize the city to make such installations, using the deposit for such purpose; otherwise, the deposit shall be returned to the subdivider upon compliance with the provisions of this section, and in default thereof may be forfeited to the city and used to cover the cost of the required installations. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-21; Code 1997, § 78-21) 
Sec. 40-22. - Underground installation of utility wires-Deposit required. 
    The subdivider of any land shall be required to install all utility service wiring below the ground within one year and, in order to guarantee the installation thereof, shall be required to deposit with the clerk a sum of money or a surety bond sufficient to cover the cost of such installation as determined by the city engineer. The deposit shall be returned to the subdivider upon compliance with the provisions of this section, and in default thereof may be forfeited to the city to be used to cover the cost of such installation. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-22; Code 1997, § 78-22) 
Sec. 40-23. - Same-Waiver of requirements. 
    The provisions of section 40-22 may be waived in total or in part by the council upon application of the subdivider when it can be shown that the location of such proposed plat is adjacent to an existing developed plat wherein the utility service lines are above ground. 
(Code 1975, § 5-20-23; Code 1997, § 78-23) 
Chapter 42 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq.; regulation by local authorities, MCL 257.605, 257.606, 257.610. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Inspection fee; determination of defective equipment. 
    There shall be an inspection fee, the amount thereof established by resolution of the city council adopted from time to time, for each inspection of a motor vehicle conducted by the department of public safety made to determine that defective equipment has been corrected. Such fee shall be payable to the city in advance of such inspection. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1-10; Code 1997, § 82-1) 
State Law reference- Vehicle inspections, MCL 257.217c. 
Secs. 42-2-42-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 42-21-42-43. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CROSSING GUARDS 

Sec. 42-44. - Position created. 
    The position of crossing guard is hereby created to perform police traffic duties under the direction of the director of public safety and in compliance with such rules and regulations as shall be promulgated by the director. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-1; Code 1997, § 82-46) 
Sec. 42-45. - Duties. 
    The duty of the crossing guard shall be to direct vehicular and pedestrian traffic at street intersections and other places in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-2; Code 1997, § 82-47) 
Sec. 42-46. - Appointment; number; work assignments. 
    Crossing guards shall be appointed by the director of public safety, who shall determine the number to be so appointed and who shall assign such crossing guards to their respective posts of duty, and the director shall also designate the hours and days when such guards shall be on duty. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-3; Code 1997, § 82-48) 
Sec. 42-47. - Oath of office; equipment. 
    Crossing guards shall be administered the oath of office by the city clerk and shall be identified by such badges, wearing apparel and insignia as the director of public safety shall determine, and shall be provided with such equipment as shall be necessary for the proper discharge of their duties. However, no crossing guard shall have on his person, when on duty, any firearm, blackjack, handcuffs or other similar or like police equipment. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-4; Code 1997, § 82-49) 
Sec. 42-48. - Rules and regulations; compensation. 
    The director of public safety shall promulgate rules relating to the qualifications, appointment and removal of crossing guards. Such persons shall be compensated at the rate from time to time fixed by the annual city salary and wage schedule. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-5; Code 1997, § 82-50) 
Sec. 42-49. - Authority limited. 
    No crossing guard shall exercise any authority as such a guard, wear the uniform or insignia of the position or display the badge of the office in any attempt to exercise authority except as shall be required during the performance of assigned duties in the regulation of traffic at such guard's assigned post. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-6; Code 1997, § 82-51) 
Sec. 42-50. - Neglect of duty. 
    No crossing guard shall knowingly or willfully neglect or refuse to respond for an assignment of duty when so required under the rules and regulations as promulgated by the director of public safety. 
(Code 1975, § 8-15-7; Code 1997, § 82-52) 
Secs. 42-51-42-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LIABILITY FOR EXPENSES 

Sec. 42-74. - Findings. 
    The city finds that a significant number of traffic arrests and accidents in the city involve drivers who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or a controlled substance. In addition, the city finds that in traffic accidents involving drivers who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or a controlled substance, there is a greater likelihood of personal injury and property damage. As a result of these determinations, a greater operational and/or financial burden is placed upon the department of public services and rescue services by persons who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or a controlled substance. 
(Code 1975, § 8-22-1; Code 1997, § 82-76; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-75. - Expenses for which reimbursement may be ordered. 
    As part of the sentence for a conviction of any of the following offenses, in addition to any other penalty authorized by law, the court may order the person convicted to reimburse the city or other local unit of government for expenses incurred in relation to that incident, including but not limited to expenses for an emergency response and expenses for prosecuting the person: 
(1)  Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance. 
(2)  Operating a motor vehicle with an unlawful blood alcohol content. 
(3)  Operating a motor vehicle when visibly impaired. 
(4)  A person who is less than 21 years of age operating a motor vehicle with any bodily alcohol content as defined in MCL 257.625(6). 
(5)  Operating a commercial motor vehicle while having a blood alcohol content of 0.04 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
(Code 1975, § 8-22-2; Code 1997, § 82-77; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-76. - Reimbursable expenses defined. 
    The expenses for which reimbursement may be ordered include all of the following: 
(1)  The salaries or wages, including overtime pay, of law enforcement personnel for time spent responding to the incident from which the conviction arose, arresting the person convicted, processing the person after the arrest, preparing reports on the incident, investigating the incident, and collecting and analyzing evidence, including, but not limited to, determining bodily alcohol content and determining the presence of and identifying controlled substances in the blood, breath or urine. 
(2)  The salaries, wages or other compensation, including overtime pay, of fire department and emergency medical service personnel, including volunteer firefighters or volunteer emergency medical service personnel, for time spent in responding to and providing firefighting, rescue, and emergency medical services in relation to the incident from which the conviction arose. 
(3)  The cost of medical supplies lost or expended by fire department and emergency medical service personnel, including volunteer firefighters or volunteer emergency medical service personnel, in providing services in relation to the incident from which the conviction arose. 
(4)  Reasonable city attorney fees involved in prosecuting the person including review of evidence, responses to demands for discovery, and time expended for attendance at pretrials, trials and appeals. 
(Code 1975, § 8-22-3; Code 1997, § 82-78; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-77. - Multiple units of government incurring expenses. 
    If police, fire department or emergency medical service personnel from more than one unit of government incurred reimbursable expenses, the court may order the person convicted to reimburse each unit of government for the expenses it incurred. 
(Code 1975, § 8-22-4; Code 1997, § 82-79; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-78. - Payment of reimbursable expenses to the clerk of the court. 
    The amount ordered to be paid under this section shall be paid to the clerk of the court, who shall transmit the appropriate amount to the unit or units of government named in the order to receive reimbursement. If not otherwise provided by the court under this section, the reimbursement ordered under this section shall be made immediately. However, the court may require that the person make the reimbursement ordered under this section within a specified period or in specified installments. 
(Code 1997, § 82-80; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-79. - Default in payment of reimbursable expenses. 
    If the person convicted is placed on probation, any reimbursement ordered under this section shall be a condition of that probation. The court may revoke probation if the person fails to comply with the order and if the person has not made a good faith effort to comply with the order. In determining whether to revoke probation, the court shall consider the person's employment status, earning ability, number of dependents, and financial resources, the willfullness of the person's failure to pay, and any other special circumstances that may have a bearing on the person's ability to pay. 
(Code 1997, § 82-81; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-80. - Enforcement of order for reimbursement. 
    An order for reimbursement under this section may be enforced by the local unit of government named in the order to receive the reimbursement in the same manner as a judgment in a civil action. 
(Code 1997, § 82-82; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Sec. 42-81. - Imprisonment for failure to make reimbursement. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, a person shall not be imprisoned, jailed, or incarcerated for a violation of probation, or otherwise, for failure to make a reimbursement as ordered under this section unless the court determines that the person has the resources to pay the ordered reimbursement and has not made a good faith effort to do so. 
(Code 1997, § 82-83; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 2-26-2001) 
Secs. 42-82-42-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STATE VEHICLE CODE 

Sec. 42-106. - Code adopted. 
    The Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq.), is adopted by reference. 
(Code 1997, § 82-391; Ord. No. 793, 5-17-2004) 
State Law reference- Authority for this section, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 42-107. - References in code. 
    References in the state vehicle code to "local authorities" shall mean the city. 
(Code 1997, § 82-392; Ord. No. 793, 5-17-2004) 
Sec. 42-108. - Penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the state vehicle code are adopted by reference; provided, however, that the city may not enforce any provisions of the state vehicle code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days, except as authorized by specific state statute. 
(Code 1997, § 82-394; Ord. No. 793, 5-17-2004; Ord. No. 849, 8-20-2012) 
Sec. 42-109. - Amendments. 
(a)  Section 627 of the state vehicle code (MCL 257.627) is hereby amended to add the following specific speed limits established in the city: 
(1)  On Mack Avenue from the north city limits to the south city limits, a maximum speed not exceeding 35 miles per hour. 
(2)  On Vernier Road from the west city limits to the east city limits, a maximum speed not exceeding 35 miles per hour. 
(3)  On all other streets, a maximum speed not to exceed 25 miles per hour. 
(4)  On all alleys, a maximum speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour. 
(b)  Any amendments made to the state vehicle code after enactment of this article are hereby adopted by reference into this article. 
(c)  Public Act No. 61 of 2003 (MCL 257.625 et seq.) is hereby adopted in its entirety by reference. 
(d)  All other amendments to the state vehicle code which were enacted since October 21, 2002, are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1997, § 82-395; Ord. No. 793, 5-17-2004) 
Sec. 42-110. - High BAC. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference MCL 257.625(1)(c) of the Michigan Vehicle Code prohibiting operating a vehicle with an alcohol blood content of 0.17 grams or more as specifically enumerated by MCL 257.625. Violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by one or more of the following: 
(1)  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
(2)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days. 
(3)  A fine of not less than $200.00, or more than $700.00. 
(Ord. No. 849, 8-20-2012) 
Secs. 42-111-42-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE 

Sec. 42-132. - Adoption. 
    The uniform traffic code for cities, townships and villages, promulgated by the director of the department of state police and published in the Michigan Administrative Code, 2002 MR 20, and amendments as published in the state administrative code, in accordance with Public Act No. 62 of 1956 (MCL 257.951 et seq.), as amended, is hereby adopted by reference as modified in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1-1; Code 1997, § 82-101) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt uniform traffic code by reference, MCL 257.951. 
Sec. 42-133. - References. 
    Reference in the uniform traffic code for cities, townships and villages to "governmental unit" shall mean the City of Grosse Pointe Woods. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1-2; Code 1997, § 82-102) 
Sec. 42-134. - Amendments. 
    The following sections and subsections of the uniform traffic code adopted in this article are hereby amended as set forth in this section, and additional sections and subsections are added as indicated. Section numbers set out in this section shall refer to the like-numbered sections in the uniform traffic code. 
R 28.1125 The director of public safety. Whenever the term "chief of police" or the term "traffic engineer" is used in such code, it shall be construed and be deemed to mean the director of public safety of the city. 
R 28.1153 Traffic control orders. 
(1)  The authority to regulate traffic contained in the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be exercised by the director of public safety by the issuance of traffic control orders that shall specify the rules and regulations adopted or established by the director. Such traffic control orders shall become effective upon being filed with the city clerk and upon erection of adequate signs or signals giving notice of the existence of such regulation, if signs or signals are required by the provisions of this article pertaining to such regulation. Traffic control orders may be either temporary or permanent and all such orders shall be filed with the city clerk. All such orders and any action modifying or repealing such orders shall be kept in a separate book by the city clerk to be known as the traffic control order book. 
(2)  Copies of traffic control orders certified by the city clerk to be a true transcript compared by the clerk with the original in the clerk's office shall be evidence in all courts and proceedings in like manner as the original would be if produced. If it shall appear that a traffic control sign, signal or device conforming to the provisions of the ordinance from which this article is derived was erected or in place when the alleged violation of this article occurred, such showing shall be prima facie evidence of the existence of a lawful traffic control order authorizing such traffic control, sign, signal or device, and it shall be unnecessary for the prosecution to affirmatively show the existence of a valid traffic control order in such cases, unless and until such presumption is rebutted by competent evidence. 
R 28.1154 The following duties prescribed for the clerk shall relate to that person who is designated by the city administrator of this governmental unit. 
R 28.1410a Speed limits. The following speed limits are hereby established in the city: 
On Mack Avenue from the north city limits to the south city limits, a maximum speed not exceeding 35 miles per hour. 
On Vernier Road from the west city limits to the east city limits, a maximum speed not exceeding 35 miles per hour. 
On all other streets, a maximum speed not to exceed 25 miles per hour. 
On all alleys, a maximum speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary hereinbefore set forth, any person driving a vehicle upon any street, highway or alley of the city shall drive such vehicle at a careful and prudent speed not greater than or less than is reasonable and proper, having due regard for the traffic, surface and width of the street, highway or alley and any other conditions then existing, and no person shall drive any vehicle upon any street, highway or alley in the city at a speed greater than will permit such person to bring such vehicle to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead; 
Nor shall any person drive any vehicle in the city under any circumstances when such speed would be unsafe; provided, that where a different speed is lawfully established and posted such lawfully established and posted speed shall prevail, notwithstanding anything to the contrary hereinabove provided. 
R 28.1713 (a) Hitchhiking. No person shall solicit a ride in any motor vehicle, other than a commercially operated bus or taxicab, in any manner or by any gesture, sign or other method within the limits of the city. A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
R 28.1713 (b) Soliciting rides; business. No person shall stand in any street, alley, highway or other public place for the purpose of soliciting a ride, employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle traveling upon any street, alley, highway or other public place unless previously authorized to do so by the city council. 
R 28.1810 (u) Parking between sidewalk and street curbing. No person shall stand or park a vehicle on that portion of the property located between the lot lines and the curb contiguous to Mack Avenue, unless authorized by written approval by the director of public safety. 
R 28.1810 (v) Trespass on posted property. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon any premises with a motor vehicle or park such vehicle upon such premises when such premises has posted thereon signs prohibiting such action, or to enter upon or park a motor vehicle upon such premises contrary to the posted permitted parking regulations on such premises. 
(Code 1975, §§ 9-1-4-9-1-6, 9-1-9, 9-1-13; Code 1997, § 82-103; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 12-20-1999; Ord. No. 760, § 1, 11-20-2000) 
Secs. 42-135-42-151. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OPERATION 

Sec. 42-152. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial vehicle means any motor-driven or horse-driven vehicle used for the purpose of carrying or transporting materials, merchandise, equipment or the like as distinguished from a vehicle used for transporting passengers only. 
    Through traffic means all commercial vehicular traffic which has for its destination a place without the city limits, or which originates without the city limits and has for its destination or route of travel Mack Avenue within the city limits. 
(Code 1975, § 9-5-2; Code 1997, § 82-131) 
Sec. 42-153. - Commercial traffic restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any commercial vehicle in, along and upon Bournemouth Avenue, for through traffic purposes, from Mack Avenue to the west city limits. 
(Code 1975, § 9-5-1; Code 1997, § 82-132) 
Sec. 42-154. - Designated; placement of stop signs. 
(a)  The following through streets are hereby designated and established in the city: 
(1)  Bramcaster Road from Prestwick Road to Huntington Boulevard. 
(2)  Charlevoix Avenue from Vernier Road to the north city limits. 
(3)  Eastbourne Road from Prestwick Road to Stanhope Avenue. 
(4)  Fairway Drive from Fairford Road to Sunningdale Drive. 
(5)  Goethe Avenue from Anita Avenue to Eight Mile Road. 
(6)  Helen Avenue from Norwood Drive to Brys Drive. 
(7)  Holiday Road from Cook Road to Sunningdale Drive. 
(8)  Jackson Avenue from Kenmore Drive to Van Antwerp Avenue. 
(9)  Mack Avenue from the south city limits to the north city limits. 
(10)  Marter Road from Vernier Road to the north city limits. 
(11)  Morningside Drive from Cook Road to Blairmoor Court. 
(12)  River Road from Brys Drive north to Moorland Drive. 
(13)  Van K Drive from Brys Drive south to Rosedale Court. 
(14)  Vernier Road from the west city limits to the east city limits. 
(15)  Wedgewood Drive from Fairford Road to Hidden Lane. 
(16)  Wedgewood Drive from Vernier Road to Moorland Drive. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director of public safety to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street intersecting such through street or streets or intersecting that portion thereof as described in subsection (a) of this section unless at any such intersection traffic is controlled at all times by traffic control signals; provided, however, that at the intersection of two of such through streets or at the intersection of a through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall be erected at the approaches of either of such streets as may be determined by the director of public safety upon the basis of an engineering or traffic study. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1-3; Code 1997, § 82-151) 
Secs. 42-155-42-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate standing or parking of vehicles, MCL 257.606(1)(a); stopping, standing or parking of vehicles, MCL 257.672 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-176. - Special permits. 
(a)  Physically incapacitated war veterans entitled to and/or using vehicles under federal legislation, or similar special constructed vehicles, shall be entitled to park such vehicle for periods not to exceed 24 hours at any one time on streets and in areas, including metered areas, where parking is limited but not prohibited, subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Any veteran so entitled shall possess a card issued by the director of public safety certifying that the holder thereof meets the requirements of this section. Such card shall be kept in the veteran's personal possession and be exhibited upon the request of any public safety officer. The vehicle, when parked, shall carry a sticker conspicuously displayed at all times on the sun visor, such sticker to be issued by the director of public safety and indicating the right to park under the provisions of this article. The director of public safety may limit the privilege granted to certain areas or streets, and may impose such other restrictions as the director may deem necessary. 
(2)  The unauthorized possession or use of such card and/or sticker is hereby declared a violation of this article. 
(b)  The provisions of this section relative to certain parking privileges for physically incapacitated war veterans may be extended to other physically incapacitated persons by the director of public safety upon a proper showing of a need therefor. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1-7; Code 1997, § 82-177) 
Sec. 42-177. - Parking of commercial vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any commercial vehicle on any street in districts R-1 and R-2 for a period longer than actually required in connection with the delivery of merchandise or materials or the rendering of any services or performance of any building construction, and in all other districts, no such vehicle shall be permitted to park between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., except for making deliveries of merchandise or materials or the rendering of any services or performance of any building construction, and then only for the actual time required to make such delivery of merchandise or materials or the rendering of any services or performance of any building construction; provided that where parking is prohibited, restricted or limited as to time, such restrictions or limitations shall be observed notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this section. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1-8; Code 1997, § 82-178) 
Sec. 42-178. - Residential parking and semicircular drives. 
    For cross reference purposes on residential parking and semicircular drives, see section 50-531. 
(Code 1997, § 82-206; Ord. No. 777, § 2, 2-25-2002) 
Secs. 42-179-42-209. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY-OWNED PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 42-210. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motor vehicle means any automobile, truck, motor scooter, motorcycle or other self-propelled vehicle. 
    Municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lot and parking lot mean such properties which are owned or leased by the city and designated by the council as metered off-street parking lots. 
    Operator means and includes every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner thereof, or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner. 
    Parking space means any area marked off by lines or markings upon the pavement of any such parking lot intended to be used for the parking of vehicles. 
    Service driveways means those portions of the parking lot set aside and intended to be used for means of ingress and egress to the parking lot and the parking spaces. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-1; Code 1997, § 82-231) 
Sec. 42-211. - Council to establish. 
    The council shall, from time to time, establish and designate properties owned or leased by the city as municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lots, which shall be subject to the regulations and provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-2; Code 1997, § 82-232) 
Sec. 42-212. - Use of lots to comply with division. 
    The use of municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lots shall be in conformity with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-3; Code 1997, § 82-233) 
Sec. 42-213. - Plans and layout. 
    The city administrator is hereby instructed to lay out or cause to be laid out municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lots so as to provide for parking spaces, service driveways and for lines or markings painted or placed upon the pavement of such parking lots to indicate such parking spaces and service driveways. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-4; Code 1997, § 82-234) 
Sec. 42-214. - Method of parking. 
    It shall be unlawful to park or stand any vehicle in a municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lot in such a position that the vehicle is not entirely within the area so designated as a parking space by such lines or markings. All vehicles parked or stood in any parking space shall be parked in such a manner so that the front of such vehicle shall be facing the parking meter designated for the parking space so occupied. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-5; Code 1997, § 82-235) 
Sec. 42-215. - Use of service driveways. 
    It shall be unlawful to use any service driveways for parking purposes or in a direction other than that designated or established by proper markings installed for such purpose of designation. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-6; Code 1997, § 82-236) 
Sec. 42-216. - Meters. 
    The city administrator shall cause to be placed parking meters on each parking space in such manner as to show or display a signal that such meter is or is not legally in use. Each parking meter shall be installed and set to display upon the deposit of the coins required to be so deposited for use of the parking space a signal indicating legal parking or standing for that period of time conforming to the limit of parking time which has been or may be established for that parking space upon which such meter is installed, and shall continue to operate from the deposit of such coin or coins therein until the expiration of the time fixed as the parking limit for the parking space upon which such meter is placed. Each meter shall be so arranged that upon the expiration of such legal parking time, it will indicate by a mechanical operation and the displaying of a proper signal that the lawful parking period has expired. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-7; Code 1997, § 82-237) 
Sec. 42-217. - Time limits; fees. 
    The city administrator, by and with the consent and approval of the council, shall establish from time to time the maximum time limit for the use of parking spaces and the fees for parking in a municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lot. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-8; Code 1997, § 82-238) 
Sec. 42-218. - Prohibited parking hours. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized to restrict the hours of the day or night during which municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lots shall be in operation, and it shall be unlawful for any operator to park any vehicle in such parking lot during the prohibited parking period. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-9; Code 1997, § 82-239) 
Sec. 42-219. - Information to be posted. 
    The city administrator shall recommend to the city council regulations to be posted by signs in the city-owned or leased off-street parking lots. Such regulations shall provide for the hours during which such lot shall be in operation, the meter fees to be charged for legal parking, the restricting of any such lot to use by certain authorized vehicles or the spaces thereon by certain authorized vehicles, and any other information required to properly advise the operators of vehicles using such parking lots of the regulations affecting the use thereof. Upon the approval of such regulations by the city council, such lots shall be posted accordingly. It shall be deemed a violation of this division for the operator or owner of a motor vehicle to park such vehicle contrary to the regulations posted at such lots. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-10; Code 1997, § 82-240) 
Sec. 42-220. - Vehicle operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator to operate any vehicle in any parking lot at a speed in excess of the speed posted therein, or in a careless and heedless manner, in willful or wanton disregard for the rights or safety of others or without due caution and circumspection, and at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or likely to endanger any person or property. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-11; Code 1997, § 82-241) 
Sec. 42-221. - Deposit of coins. 
    When any vehicle shall be parked or shall be left standing in any parking space, the operator of such vehicle, upon entering such parking space, shall immediately deposit or cause to be deposited in the parking meter coins of United States currency for the lawful period of parking desired by such operator, and shall place in operation such meter and such parking space may then be lawfully occupied by such vehicle during the period of parking or standing time which has been prescribed for such parking space, and which has been paid for by the meter deposit. If such vehicle shall remain parked or shall remain standing in any such parking space beyond the parking or standing time limit fixed for each parking space, the parking meter shall display a sign or signal showing illegal parking or standing. In that event, such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of legal parking or standing time, and the parking or standing of a vehicle in such parking space shall be a violation of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-12; Code 1997, § 82-242) 
Sec. 42-222. - Overtime parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any motor vehicle to stand or to be parked overtime beyond the period of legal parking or standing time established for any parking space, or to stand at or remain parked at a meter after the time period paid for by the deposit of a coin in such meter has expired, as indicated by the red violation tag of such meter. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-13; Code 1997, § 82-243) 
Sec. 42-223. - Parking time extension. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this division for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in a parking meter additional coins of United States currency for the purpose of increasing or extending the parking or standing time of any vehicle beyond the legal parking or standing time which has been established for the parking space adjacent to which such parking meter is placed. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-14; Code 1997, § 82-244) 
Sec. 42-224. - Substitute coins and slugs. 
    It shall be unlawful to deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, devices or substitutes for any coin of the United States. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-15; Code 1997, § 82-245) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 752.801. 
Sec. 42-225. - Damage to meters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter, sign or other equipment or structure installed under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-16; Code 1997, § 82-246) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief generally, MCL 750.377a et seq. 
Sec. 42-226. - Vehicle owner responsible for violations. 
    In any proceeding for violation of the provisions of this division or any parking rule or regulation adopted pursuant to the provisions of the parking laws of the city, the registration plate displayed on the motor vehicle shall constitute a prima facie presumption that the owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where such violation occurred. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-17; Code 1997, § 82-247) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 257.675c. 
Sec. 42-227. - Disposition of revenue. 
    The coins required to be deposited in parking meters as provided in this division, or any amendments thereto, are hereby levied and assessed to provide for the proper regulation and control of parking in the municipally owned and operated off-street metered parking lots. The coins deposited in such meters shall be collected by the duly authorized agents of the city treasurer, and shall be deposited by the treasurer in a special fund to be known as the parking meter fund, from which fund, upon duly approved vouchers, payments shall be made to cover the cost of acquiring the property for such parking lots and for installing parking meters, costs of supervision, inspection service, maintenance, supply of parts, the cost of collection and the enforcement of this division. Any balance remaining after the use of the funds as provided in this section shall be used for the reimbursement of funds advanced for the acquisition, improvement and placing in operation of such parking lots, for the acquisition, construction and operation of additional parking facilities, or for such other lawful purpose as the council shall direct. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4-18; Code 1997, § 82-248) 
Secs. 42-228-42-247. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OFF-STREET PARKING LOTS AND PARKING METER ZONES 

Sec. 42-248. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motor vehicle means any automobile, truck, motor scooter, motorcycle or other self-propelled vehicle. 
    Municipally owned off-street parking lot and parking lot mean any property owned or leased by the city and designated by the city council as an off-street parking lot. 
    Operator means and includes every individual who shall operate a vehicle, whether such operation shall be by the title holder or his agent, employee or permittee. 
    Parking space means any area marked off by lines painted upon the pavement of any off-street parking lot or street intended to be used for the parking of vehicles and designating such parking area. 
    Service driveway means those portions of municipally owned off-street parking lots set aside and intended to be used for means of ingress and egress to and from the parking lot and parking spaces. 
    Street means any public street, avenue, road, boulevard, highway or other public place established for the use of vehicles. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3-1; Code 1997, § 82-271) 
Sec. 42-249. - Designation of off-street parking lots. 
    The city council shall, from time to time, establish and designate properties owned or leased by the city as off-street parking lots, which lots shall be subject to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3-2; Code 1997, § 82-272) 
Sec. 42-250. - Establishment of parking spaces. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized to establish parking spaces on streets and municipally owned off-street parking lots so as to provide for parking spaces on such streets and lots and service driveways in such lots and to establish pavement markings for such parking spaces and service driveways. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3-3; Code 1997, § 82-273) 
Sec. 42-251. - Parking meter zones-Designation. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized and directed to establish immediately, and from time to time hereafter, where in the administrator's opinion traffic conditions warrant the same, zones to be known as parking meter zones, upon such streets and municipally owned off-street parking lots as are selected by the city administrator for the location of such zones, and therein the city administrator shall cause parking meters to be installed, and shall cause parking meter spaces to be designated as provided in this division. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3-4; Code 1997, § 82-274) 
Sec. 42-252. - Same-Placement and operation. 
    Parking meters installed in the parking meter zones established as provided in section 42-251 shall be placed upon the curb immediately adjacent to the individual parking places described in this section. Each parking meter shall be placed or set in such manner as to show or display by a signal that the parking space adjacent to such meter is or is not legally in use. Each parking meter shall be installed and set to display upon the deposit of coins, in United States currency, therein, a signal indicating legal parking or standing for that period of time conforming to the limit of parking time which has been or may be established for that area or zone of the street or parking lots upon which such parking meter is installed, and shall continue to operate from the time of the deposit of such coin therein until the expiration of the time fixed as the parking limit for the part of the street or parking lot upon which such meter is placed. Each meter shall also be so arranged that upon the expiration of such legal parking time it will indicate by a mechanical operation and the displaying of proper signal that the lawful parking period has expired. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3-5; Code 1997, § 82-275) 
Sec. 42-253. - Method of parking. 
    Each vehicle parking or standing alongside of or next to any parking space on any street or upon any municipally owned off-street parking lot shall park or stand within the lines or markings so established. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this division to park or stand any vehicle in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. When a parking space in any meter zone is parallel with the adjacent curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parking or standing in such parking space shall be parked or stood so that the foremost part of such vehicle shall be alongside of and nearest to the parking meter. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3-6; Code 1997, § 82-276) 
Sec. 42-254. - Use of meters.
